actions.text: Collaborate with coastal cities worldwide to develop a global network for sharing best practices in sustainable fisheries management and supporting vulnerable fishing communities.

target_actors.text: Global Alliance for Sustainable Fisheries and Resilient Coastal Communities (GASFRC)

tasks.text: GASFRC, GSFA, and the Essaouira Regional Sustainable Fisheries Council can jointly establish a knowledge-sharing platform to facilitate collaboration and disseminate best practices among coastal cities worldwide, focusing on sustainable fisheries management and supporting vulnerable fishing communities.

updates.text: The GASFRC-GSFA-Essaouira knowledge-sharing platform is live, with 25 coastal cities already participating. Best practices on sustainable fishing gear, catch limits, and community support programs have been shared. Next steps: expand city participation, host a virtual symposium, and develop joint policy recommendations for the 2024 UN Ocean Conference.

The Global Sustainable Fisheries Network, initiated by the Moroccan assembly in collaboration with coastal cities worldwide, has launched an online knowledge-sharing platform. It enables fishing communities to exchange best practices, access resources, and advocate for supportive policies at national and international levels, strengthening the collective voice of artisanal fishers.

details.name: Arawa Climate Gathering
details.purpose: We are running this assembly in Arawa to bring together diverse voices from our community to discuss the challenges and opportunities around food security, traditional farming practices, and building a sustainable and resilient food system in the face of climate change and other global crises affecting Bougainville.
details.background: Arawa, the main town in the Autonomous Region of Bougainville, Papua New Guinea, is rebuilding after a prolonged civil conflict. Subsistence farming and fishing are the primary food sources, with limited access to imported goods. Climate change impacts, such as rising sea levels and extreme weather events, threaten food security and traditional livelihoods. The region faces challenges in balancing sustainable food production with economic development and post-conflict reconstruction efforts, while navigating its complex relationship with the national government and international stakeholders.
details.organisation_description: Arawa Community Food Security Initiative is a grassroots organization in Bougainville, Papua New Guinea, promoting sustainable agriculture, food sovereignty, and community resilience through education, resource sharing, and collaborative projects.
details.supporters_description:
National Government: The Papua New Guinea national government is providing funding to the Arawa Community Food Security Initiative through grants from the Ministry of Agriculture and Livestock. The government is also offering technical support and expertise to help the initiative develop sustainable agricultural practices and improve food distribution systems.

Faith-Based Organization: The Catholic Diocese of Bougainville is actively supporting the Arawa Community Food Security Initiative by mobilizing its network of churches and community groups to raise awareness about the importance of food security. The diocese is also providing volunteers to assist with community gardens, food distribution, and educational programs on nutrition and sustainable farming methods.
details.funders_description: The Catholic Diocese of Bougainville, a faith-based organization, is supporting the community assembly in Arawa, Bougainville, Papua New Guinea, as part of its mission to promote social justice, environmental stewardship, and community well-being. The Diocese recognizes the importance of engaging local communities in discussions about sustainable food systems and the challenges posed by the interconnected planetary crises. By providing financial and logistical support for the assembly, the Catholic Diocese of Bougainville aims to foster dialogue, knowledge sharing, and collective action among the people of Arawa, in line with its commitment to integral human development and care for creation.
details.recruitment_criteria: WHAT FORMAT? Setting demographic parameters? Living within a certain distance? Freeform text?

actions.text: Develop a community-based sustainable agriculture program that integrates traditional knowledge with modern practices to enhance food security and resilience in the face of climate change.

target_actors.text: Arawa Sustainable Agriculture and Traditional Knowledge Initiative (ASATKI)
Bougainville Center for Sustainable Agriculture and Traditional Knowledge (BCSATK)

tasks.text: The community assembly participants can support the collaboration between ASATKI, BSAN, and BCSATK to create a comprehensive plan for implementing sustainable agriculture practices that combine traditional wisdom and modern innovations, ensuring food security and resilience for the local community.

updates.text:
Progress Update:
ASATKI, BSAN, and BCSATK have formed a joint committee to develop a sustainable agriculture plan. They have conducted surveys to assess local needs and resources. Pilot projects integrating traditional crop rotation with modern irrigation techniques are underway in three villages, with promising early results in crop yields and water efficiency.

The community-based sustainable agriculture program has inspired similar initiatives in neighboring villages. Representatives from these communities recently gathered to share knowledge and resources, fostering a growing regional network committed to enhancing food security and resilience through the integration of traditional and modern agricultural practices.

actions.text: Establish a community-managed marine protected area to safeguard coastal ecosystems, ensure sustainable fishing practices, and protect traditional livelihoods from the impacts of climate change.

tasks.text: The community assembly participants could advocate for increased funding, resources, and legal authority to be granted to the Arawa Coastal Guardians, Arawa Local Marine Conservation Council, and Autonomous Bougainville Coastal Conservation Authority to enable them to effectively establish and manage the proposed marine protected area.

updates.text: After weeks of advocacy, the Arawa Coastal Guardians and Conservation Council have secured initial funding and legal authority to establish the marine protected area. Community consultations are underway to define boundaries and management plans. Next steps include finalizing the conservation framework and beginning implementation to safeguard coastal ecosystems and livelihoods.

The community-managed marine protected area has inspired similar initiatives across Papua New Guinea. The national government has taken notice and is now working on legislation to support the establishment of a network of locally-governed marine reserves, aiming to protect both coastal ecosystems and traditional livelihoods in the face of climate change.

actions.text: Advocate for the inclusion of indigenous voices and knowledge in global climate governance discussions to ensure equitable and culturally appropriate solutions for vulnerable communities worldwide.

tasks.text: BICAN can mobilize its networks to lobby global climate governance bodies to include indigenous representatives and perspectives in decision-making processes, ensuring solutions address the unique needs and rights of vulnerable communities.

updates.text: Progress Update: BICAN representatives have met with UN climate officials to discuss formally including indigenous voices in COP28 and beyond. Ongoing discussions are establishing mechanisms for indigenous knowledge-holders to shape climate policies and solutions. Key UN members are receptive, and a draft plan is being developed for equitable representation.

Indigenous leaders from Papua New Guinea presented their climate adaptation strategies at the UN Climate Change Conference, sharing traditional knowledge and advocating for its integration into global climate policies. This has sparked increased interest from other nations in learning from and collaborating with indigenous communities on climate solutions.

details.name: Hà Giang Food Gathering
details.purpose: We are running this assembly in Đồng Văn to bring together diverse community members to discuss the challenges and opportunities around food systems in the context of climate change and environmental pressures, and to collectively envision a more sustainable and resilient future for our region.
details.background: Đồng Văn, a rural district in Hà Giang province, faces challenges in food security due to its mountainous terrain and limited agricultural land. The local ethnic minority communities rely on subsistence farming, growing rice, maize, and vegetables. However, climate change, soil degradation, and limited access to modern farming techniques hinder productivity. The region also grapples with poverty, malnutrition, and limited market access for agricultural products. Addressing these issues requires sustainable agricultural practices, improved infrastructure, and policies that support small-scale farmers while considering the global context of food systems and environmental challenges.
details.organisation_description: Đồng Văn Sustainable Food Initiative promotes eco-friendly farming, local food systems, and community resilience in Đồng Văn, Hà Giang, Vietnam, through education, collaboration, and innovative agricultural practices.
details.supporters_description:
Philanthropic Organization: The Rockefeller Foundation, a philanthropic organization based in New York, has pledged $500,000 to support the Đồng Văn Sustainable Food Initiative. The funds will be used to provide training and resources to local farmers, helping them adopt sustainable agricultural practices and improve their livelihoods. The foundation will also work with local NGOs to establish a network of community gardens and promote food security in the region.

National Government: The Vietnamese Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Development has recognized the Đồng Văn Sustainable Food Initiative as a model for sustainable agriculture in the country. The government has allocated $1.2 million to support the initiative over the next five years. The funds will be used to improve infrastructure, such as irrigation systems and storage facilities, and to provide subsidies for farmers who adopt sustainable practices. The government will also work with local authorities to develop policies that promote sustainable agriculture and protect the region's unique biodiversity.
details.funders_description: The Catholic Relief Services (CRS), a faith-based organization, is supporting a community assembly in Đồng Văn, Hà Giang, Vietnam as part of their global initiative to promote sustainable agriculture and food security in rural communities. CRS recognizes the importance of engaging local communities in dialogue and decision-making processes to address the challenges posed by climate change, environmental degradation, and socio-economic inequalities. By facilitating this community assembly, CRS aims to foster collaboration between farmers, local authorities, and religious leaders to develop context-specific solutions that align with the community's values and beliefs while ensuring the long-term resilience of their food systems.
details.recruitment_criteria: WHAT FORMAT? Setting demographic parameters? Living within a certain distance? Freeform text?

actions.text: Promote agroforestry practices that integrate crop cultivation with tree planting to improve soil health, biodiversity, and climate resilience while diversifying income sources for local farmers.

tasks.text: The community assembly participants can support the Đồng Văn Agroforestry Cooperative in implementing agroforestry practices by providing resources, knowledge sharing, and advocating for policies that incentivize the adoption of these sustainable farming methods.

updates.text: 37 local farmers have joined the Đồng Văn Agroforestry Cooperative, which has planted 2,000 trees alongside crops. Soil health is improving, and farmers are learning new techniques. The cooperative is advocating for government incentives to expand agroforestry in the region, with support from the community assembly participants.

The Vietnamese government has launched a nationwide agroforestry initiative, inspired by the community assembly's recommendations. The program provides training and financial incentives to farmers adopting integrated crop-tree systems. Early reports show improved soil health and increased biodiversity in pilot areas, with plans to expand the initiative globally through the assembly network.

actions.text: Establish a community seed bank to preserve local crop diversity and ensure access to resilient, adaptable seed varieties for farmers in the face of climate change.

target_actors.text: Đồng Văn Community Seed Preservation Initiative

tasks.text: The Đồng Văn Community Seed Preservation Initiative can set up a secure facility to store and catalog diverse local seed varieties, and create a system for farmers to access and share these seeds to enhance their resilience to climate impacts.

updates.text: Two months since the assembly, the Đồng Văn Community Seed Bank has been established in a secure facility. Over 50 local crop varieties have been cataloged so far. A system is in place for farmers to access and share these resilient seeds, bolstering their adaptability to climate change impacts.

actions.text: Develop a community-based agro-tourism program that showcases sustainable farming practices, supports local livelihoods, and promotes cultural exchange between visitors and ethnic minority communities.

tasks.text: The community assembly participants could provide input on the design of the agro-tourism program, identify key sustainable farming practices and cultural elements to showcase, and help recruit local farmers and artisans to participate in the cooperative.

updates.text:
Progress Update:
The cooperative has been established with 12 local farmers and artisans. Guided farm tours and traditional craft workshops are being developed. Partnerships with regional tourism boards are underway to promote the program. Challenges include ensuring fair compensation for participants and managing visitor numbers to maintain sustainability.

actions.text: Establish a network of local food processing and preservation hubs to reduce post-harvest losses, add value to agricultural products, and improve food security for the community.

target_actors.text: Đồng Văn Community Food Processing and Preservation Network (ĐVCFPPN)

tasks.text: The community assembly participants can support the collaboration between ĐVCFPPN and Đồng Văn District People's Committee to set up food processing and preservation facilities, provide training, and develop a sustainable business model for the local food hub network.

updates.text: Two months after the assembly, ĐVCFPPN and Đồng Văn District People's Committee have identified potential sites for three local food hubs. Feasibility studies are underway to assess infrastructure needs and develop business plans. Discussions with farmers and cooperatives have begun to gauge interest and secure commitments for supplying the hubs.

The local food processing and preservation hub network has expanded to five new communities in Vietnam. Inspired by this success, the national government has launched a funding program to support the establishment of similar hubs across the country, aiming to reduce food waste and enhance food security nationwide.

actions.text: Collaborate with indigenous communities in the Amazon to exchange knowledge on sustainable farming practices and adapt them to the local context, considering the global impact of deforestation on climate change.

target_actors.text: Đồng Văn Indigenous Agroecology Research Center

tasks.text: The community assembly participants could facilitate connections and knowledge-sharing between the Đồng Văn Indigenous Agroforestry Alliance, Amazonian Indigenous Agroecology Network, and Đồng Văn Indigenous Agroecology Research Center to adapt sustainable Amazonian farming practices to the local context while considering global deforestation impacts.

updates.text: The Đồng Văn and Amazonian agroecology networks have begun collaborating, with researchers visiting each other's communities to learn and adapt sustainable farming practices. Initial trials adapting Amazonian techniques in Đồng Văn show promise for reducing deforestation while improving yields. More extensive knowledge exchanges and local adaptation efforts are planned.

details.name: Svalbard Climate Conversation
details.purpose: We are organizing this assembly in Longyearbyen to engage our community in discussing the challenges and opportunities related to food security and sustainability in the Arctic, as we face the impacts of climate change and the need for resilient local food systems in our unique and fragile environment.
details.background: Longyearbyen, the northernmost town in the world, faces unique challenges in food security due to its remote Arctic location. With a harsh climate and permafrost, local food production is limited, making the community heavily reliant on imported goods. The effects of climate change, including melting glaciers and shifting wildlife patterns, further threaten the delicate balance of the local ecosystem. As global supply chains become increasingly vulnerable to disruptions, ensuring a stable and sustainable food supply for Longyearbyen's residents is a pressing concern that requires innovative solutions and international cooperation.
details.organisation_description: Longyearbyen Community Action Network (LCAN) is a grassroots organization in Longyearbyen, Svalbard, dedicated to addressing local environmental and social issues through community engagement, education, and collaborative projects.
details.supporters_description:
Academic Institution: The University Centre in Svalbard (UNIS) is collaborating with LCAN by providing research expertise, data analysis, and scientific insights related to food security and sustainability in the Arctic region. UNIS faculty and students are actively involved in LCAN's projects, offering their knowledge and skills to support the organization's initiatives.

Regional Government: The Governor of Svalbard (Sysselmannen) is partnering with LCAN to develop and implement policies and regulations that promote sustainable food practices and address food-related challenges in Longyearbyen. The regional government provides funding, resources, and administrative support to help LCAN achieve its goals and engage the local community in decision-making processes.
details.funders_description: The Norwegian Confederation of Trade Unions (LO) is supporting a community assembly in Longyearbyen, Svalbard, to discuss the impact of climate change on the local food system and the livelihoods of workers in the region. As the archipelago faces rapid environmental changes, including melting permafrost and shifting wildlife patterns, LO recognizes the need to involve workers in developing strategies for adaptation and resilience. By facilitating a dialogue between union members, community leaders, and experts, LO aims to ensure that the voices of workers are heard in shaping policies that affect their lives and the future of their community in the face of interconnected planetary crises.
details.recruitment_criteria: WHAT FORMAT? Setting demographic parameters? Living within a certain distance? Freeform text?

actions.text: Develop a community-driven, climate-resilient food storage and distribution system to ensure food security during supply chain disruptions and extreme weather events.

tasks.text: The community assembly participants could collaborate with the Svalbard Community Food Resilience Network and Longyearbyen Municipal Council to design and implement a robust, locally-managed food storage and distribution infrastructure that leverages traditional knowledge and modern technology to withstand climate-related disruptions.

updates.text: The Longyearbyen community has begun construction on a new climate-resilient food storage facility, incorporating traditional Svalbard design elements and modern insulation technology. A committee of local leaders, farmers, and logistics experts are developing protocols for equitable food distribution during emergencies. Outreach is underway to engage more residents in the initiative.

actions.text: Establish a research program to explore innovative, sustainable, and locally-adapted food production methods suitable for Longyearbyen's unique Arctic environment, such as vertical farming and permaculture techniques.

target_actors.text: Svalbard Arctic Sustainable Agriculture Research Institute (SASARI)

tasks.text: The community assembly participants could advocate for increased funding and resources to be allocated to SASARI, SSFIC, and the Longyearbyen Municipal Council to support the establishment of a comprehensive research program focused on developing sustainable, Arctic-adapted food production methods for Longyearbyen.

updates.text: The Longyearbyen Municipal Council has approved initial funding for a pilot research project in partnership with SASARI and SSFIC. The project will test the feasibility of vertical farming using locally-sourced materials and permaculture techniques adapted for the Arctic climate. Researchers aim to have preliminary results by next spring.

The Longyearbyen Sustainable Food Research Initiative has partnered with the Global Assembly Network to share its findings on Arctic-adapted vertical farming techniques. The initiative's success has inspired the Svalbard government to invest in sustainable food production, aiming to reduce reliance on imported goods and enhance local food security.

actions.text: Develop a comprehensive plan to attract and support sustainable food businesses and entrepreneurs to establish operations in Longyearbyen, fostering a thriving local food economy.

tasks.text: The community assembly participants could advocate for collaboration between the Longyearbyen Municipal Council, Svalbard Sustainable Food Initiative, and local entrepreneurs to create incentives, infrastructure, and resources that attract and nurture sustainable food businesses in Longyearbyen.

updates.text: Progress Update: The Longyearbyen Municipal Council has partnered with the Svalbard Sustainable Food Initiative to develop a strategic plan for attracting sustainable food businesses. They have identified potential incentives, including subsidized rent for eco-friendly facilities. Two entrepreneurs have expressed interest in establishing locally-sourced, plant-based food production in Longyearbyen.

actions.text: Collaborate with Indigenous communities in the Arctic to learn from their traditional food preservation techniques and adapt them to Longyearbyen's context, promoting cultural exchange and resilience.

tasks.text: ARX, Longyearbyen Municipal Council, and SAIKI can organize workshops and knowledge-sharing sessions to facilitate the exchange of traditional food preservation techniques between Indigenous Arctic communities and Longyearbyen residents.

updates.text: Since the assembly, ARX and SAIKI have held two successful workshops with Inuit elders, sharing their traditional food drying and fermentation techniques. Longyearbyen residents are now adapting these methods using local ingredients. The Municipal Council is planning further sessions to continue this valuable cultural exchange and build community resilience.

details.name: Maracaibo Food Meeting
details.purpose: We are running this assembly to bring together diverse voices from Maracaibo to discuss the challenges and opportunities around food in the face of Venezuela's economic crisis and global environmental pressures. Our goal is to identify community-driven solutions to improve food security, sustainability and resilience in Zulia state.
details.background: Maracaibo, the capital of Zulia state, faces food insecurity due to Venezuela's economic crisis, hyperinflation, and supply chain disruptions. The region's reliance on oil exports has left it vulnerable to global market fluctuations. Climate change-induced droughts have impacted agricultural production, while political instability and international sanctions have further exacerbated food access issues. The combination of local and global factors has led to rising food prices, scarcity of essential goods, and increased malnutrition rates, particularly affecting low-income households in Maracaibo.
details.organisation_name: Sindicato de Trabajadores Unidos de Maracaibo (STUM)
details.organisation_description: Sindicato de Trabajadores Unidos de Maracaibo (STUM) is a prominent labor union representing workers across various industries in Maracaibo, Zulia, Venezuela, advocating for fair wages and improved working conditions.
details.supporters_description:
Community Based Organization: The Asociación de Vecinos de Maracaibo, a local community organization, is collaborating with STUM to organize workshops and seminars to educate workers about their rights and the benefits of joining a labor union. They are also providing meeting spaces for STUM members and helping to distribute informational materials in the community.

For-Profit Business: Panadería La Maracucha, a local bakery in Maracaibo, is actively supporting STUM by allowing the union to hold meetings in their break room after business hours. The bakery owner, a strong believer in workers' rights, also provides discounted meals for STUM members during these meetings and encourages their employees to join the union.
details.funders_description: An individual philanthropist, originally from Maracaibo but now based in Europe, has decided to fund a community assembly in their hometown. Having witnessed the challenges faced by the local population due to economic instability and food insecurity, they believe that a deliberative process involving diverse community members could help identify innovative, context-specific solutions. The philanthropist hopes that by supporting this assembly, they can contribute to building resilience and fostering positive change in the region they still call home.
details.recruitment_criteria: WHAT FORMAT? Setting demographic parameters? Living within a certain distance? Freeform text?

actions.text: Establish community-led urban gardens to boost local food production and reduce reliance on external supply chains.

tasks.text: HUM can provide training, resources, and land access to empower residents to establish and maintain urban gardens throughout Maracaibo.

updates.text: Progress Update: HUM has partnered with local organizations to secure land for 5 urban garden sites. Training workshops have begun, with 75 residents participating so far. Resource kits have been distributed to support garden establishment. Two gardens are already producing their first harvests, enhancing local food security in Maracaibo.

actions.text: Develop a community-based food distribution network to ensure equitable access to affordable, nutritious food for vulnerable populations in Maracaibo.

target_actors.text: Red de Distribución Alimentaria Comunitaria de Maracaibo (REDACOM)

tasks.text: The community assembly participants could support the collaboration between REDACOM, RACOM, and the Maracaibo Mayor's Office to establish a well-coordinated, community-driven food distribution system that prioritizes the needs of vulnerable populations.

updates.text: Progress Update: REDACOM, RACOM, and the Maracaibo Mayor's Office have established a joint task force to develop a community-based food distribution network. Initial mapping of vulnerable populations and potential distribution points is complete. Pilot program to launch in two neighborhoods next month, with plans for city-wide expansion by year-end.

actions.text: Implement a food waste reduction and redistribution program to divert surplus food from businesses to community food banks and soup kitchens.

tasks.text: The community assembly participants can support the collaboration between Alimenta Maracaibo, Alimento Solidario Maracaibo (ASM), and Alcaldía de Maracaibo to establish a comprehensive food waste reduction and redistribution network that efficiently collects surplus food from businesses and distributes it to community food banks and soup kitchens.

updates.text:
Progress Update:
Alimenta Maracaibo, ASM, and Alcaldía de Maracaibo have successfully launched the food waste reduction and redistribution program. In the first month, over 2,000 pounds of surplus food were collected from local businesses and distributed to 5 community food banks and soup kitchens, providing meals to hundreds of individuals in need.

actions.text: Promote the cultivation of drought-resistant, nutrient-dense crops to enhance local food production and improve community nutrition in the face of climate change impacts.

target_actors.text: Instituto de Investigación Agrícola Sustentable de Maracaibo (IIASM)

tasks.text: FUNCOREMA, IIASM, and the Alcaldía de Maracaibo can collaborate to research, develop, and disseminate drought-resistant, nutrient-dense crop varieties to local farmers, while providing training and support to ensure successful cultivation and improved community nutrition.

updates.text: Two months post-assembly, FUNCOREMA, IIASM, and Alcaldía de Maracaibo have initiated trials of five promising drought-resistant, nutrient-dense crop varieties. Early results show 20% higher yields compared to traditional crops. Training programs are being developed to support local farmers in adopting these new varieties for the upcoming planting season.

actions.text: Advocate for international support to address the humanitarian crisis in Maracaibo and ensure food security for its most vulnerable residents, particularly children and the elderly.

target_actors.text: Global Alliance for Food Security in Maracaibo (GAFSM)
Red de Acción Humanitaria de Maracaibo (RAHM)

tasks.text: The community assembly participants could write letters to their elected representatives and the leadership of GAFSM, FAM, and RAHM urging them to collaborate on a comprehensive plan to address the food crisis in Maracaibo, prioritizing the needs of children and the elderly.

updates.text: Two months on, over 500 letters were sent to officials and aid organizations, resulting in increased international attention on Maracaibo's crisis. GAFSM, FAM and RAHM are now coordinating a joint relief effort focused on providing nutritional support and food aid to the city's most vulnerable children and elderly residents.

details.name: České Budějovice Climate Conversation
details.purpose: We are organizing this assembly to engage our community in a dialogue about the future of food in the face of global challenges. By bringing together diverse perspectives, we hope to identify local solutions that contribute to a more sustainable and resilient food system for České Budějovice and beyond.
details.background: České Budějovice, a city in South Bohemia, faces challenges related to food security and sustainability. The region's agricultural sector is impacted by climate change, with droughts affecting crop yields. Rising energy costs and global supply chain disruptions have led to increased food prices. The city's population is concerned about access to affordable, healthy food options. Local initiatives, such as community gardens and farmers' markets, aim to promote sustainable food production and consumption. However, more systemic changes are needed to address the interconnected issues of climate change, biodiversity loss, and social inequalities that threaten the region's food system.
details.organisation_name: University of South Bohemia in České Budějovice
details.organisation_description: The University of South Bohemia in České Budějovice is a public university located in České Budějovice, offering a wide range of undergraduate and graduate programs in various disciplines.
details.supporters_description:
Regional Government: The Regional Government of Jihočeský kraj provides funding for research projects and scholarships at the University of South Bohemia in České Budějovice. It also collaborates with the university on regional development initiatives and supports the creation of internship opportunities for students within local government agencies.

Social Movement: A grassroots social movement focused on environmental sustainability has partnered with the University of South Bohemia in České Budějovice to organize public lectures, workshops, and community events on campus. The movement also works with faculty members to conduct research on sustainable agriculture practices and promotes the university's efforts in developing eco-friendly technologies.
details.funders_description: The Czech-Moravian Confederation of Trade Unions (ČMKOS), the largest trade union confederation in the Czech Republic, is supporting the community assembly in České Budějovice, Jihočeský kraj, as part of their efforts to promote workers' rights and advocate for a just transition towards sustainable food systems. The trade union recognizes that the current food system, characterized by industrialized agriculture and long supply chains, has significant impacts on workers in the food sector, including job insecurity, low wages, and exposure to health risks. By supporting the community assembly, ČMKOS aims to amplify the voices of workers in the food sector and ensure that their concerns and perspectives are taken into account in the discussions about the future of food in the context of planetary crises. The trade union believes that a more sustainable and equitable food system can only be achieved through the active participation and empowerment of workers and local communities.
details.recruitment_criteria: WHAT FORMAT? Setting demographic parameters? Living within a certain distance? Freeform text?

actions.text: Develop a comprehensive urban agriculture strategy to increase local food production, reduce reliance on imports, and improve access to fresh, nutritious food for all residents.

target_actors.text: Jihočeský Regional Council for Sustainable Food Systems (JRCSFS)

tasks.text: The community assembly participants could advocate for and support the Municipality of České Budějovice and Jihočeský Regional Council for Sustainable Food Systems (JRCSFS) in developing and implementing a comprehensive urban agriculture strategy that increases local food production, reduces reliance on imports, and improves access to fresh, nutritious food for all residents.

updates.text: The Municipality and JRCSFS have begun drafting an urban agriculture strategy. Key stakeholders from local government, community gardens, and food justice organizations have been engaged. Initial proposals include expanding community garden plots, offering training programs, and providing incentives for urban farmers. The strategy is on track for completion next quarter.

The Czech government, inspired by the community assembly's proposal, has launched a national urban agriculture initiative. The program provides funding and resources to cities across the country to develop local food production strategies, with the goal of enhancing food security and sustainability nationwide.

actions.text: Establish a regional food policy council to coordinate efforts across sectors and develop a holistic, resilient, and equitable food system for South Bohemia.

target_actors.text: South Bohemian Regional Council for Food System Resilience and Equity

tasks.text: The community assembly participants could advocate for and support the establishment of the South Bohemian Regional Council for Food System Resilience and Equity, which would work in collaboration with the South Bohemian Regional Council to create a comprehensive plan for a sustainable and fair regional food system.

updates.text:
Progress Update:
The South Bohemian Regional Council has approved the formation of the Food System Resilience and Equity Council. Representatives from various sectors have been appointed, and the first meeting is scheduled for next month to begin developing a comprehensive plan for a sustainable and equitable regional food system.

The South Bohemian Food Policy Council has connected with similar councils across the Czech Republic to advocate for a national sustainable food strategy. They are also sharing best practices with a global network of regional food policy councils to accelerate the transition to resilient local food systems worldwide.

actions.text: Collaborate with Indigenous communities in the Amazon to learn from their sustainable agroforestry practices and adapt them to the local context, promoting biodiversity and climate resilience.

target_actors.text: Institute for Sustainable Agroforestry Adaptation (ISAA), University of South Bohemia

tasks.text: The community assembly participants could support the collaboration between AAA, ISAA, and ACAA by raising awareness, providing resources, and advocating for policies that facilitate knowledge exchange and adaptation of sustainable agroforestry practices from the Amazon to their local context.

updates.text:
Progress Update:
Local farmers and Indigenous representatives met to discuss agroforestry techniques. Three pilot sites were established to test adapted practices. Community members organized fundraisers and petitioned the local government for additional resources. Preliminary results show increased biodiversity and soil health at the pilot sites compared to conventional farms.

details.name: Littoral Resilience Assembly
details.purpose: We are running this assembly in Douala to bring together diverse voices from our community to discuss the challenges and opportunities around food in the face of climate change, biodiversity loss, and social inequalities. Through inclusive dialogue, we aim to identify local solutions for a sustainable food future.
details.background: In Douala, Littoral, Cameroon, food insecurity is a pressing issue exacerbated by climate change, rapid urbanization, and economic challenges. The region faces deforestation, soil degradation, and declining agricultural productivity. Rising food prices and limited access to nutritious food disproportionately affect vulnerable populations. Douala's position as a major port city highlights the interconnectedness of local food systems with global trade and supply chains. Addressing food security in Douala requires a holistic approach that considers environmental sustainability, social equity, and economic resilience in the face of global systemic issues.
details.organisation_name: Douala Food Security and Sustainability Initiative (DFSSI)
details.organisation_description: Douala Food Security and Sustainability Initiative (DFSSI) is a grassroots organization in Douala, Cameroon, promoting sustainable agriculture, food access, and community resilience through education, urban farming, and local partnerships.
details.supporters_description:
Regional Government: The Littoral Regional Council provides funding for DFSSI's community garden projects and supports their efforts to promote sustainable agriculture practices. The council also facilitates partnerships between DFSSI and local schools to educate students about food security and environmental stewardship.

International Organization: The United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) collaborates with DFSSI to implement projects focused on improving food access and nutrition in vulnerable communities. FAO provides technical expertise, training, and resources to support DFSSI's initiatives, such as establishing urban food banks and promoting the cultivation of indigenous crops.
details.funders_description: The Kofi Annan Foundation, a philanthropic organization dedicated to promoting sustainable development and addressing global challenges, is supporting a community assembly in Douala, Littoral, Cameroon. The foundation recognizes the importance of engaging local communities in discussions about food security and sustainability, particularly in the context of climate change and its impact on agricultural practices in the region. By funding this assembly, the Kofi Annan Foundation aims to facilitate dialogue, knowledge sharing, and the development of community-driven solutions to enhance food resilience and promote sustainable food systems in Douala and the surrounding areas.
details.recruitment_criteria: WHAT FORMAT? Setting demographic parameters? Living within a certain distance? Freeform text?

actions.text: Develop urban agriculture initiatives to increase local food production and improve access to fresh, nutritious produce for urban residents.

tasks.text: The community assembly participants could advocate for and support collaboration between Douala City Council and Green Harvest Douala to identify suitable urban spaces, provide resources, and engage the community in establishing and maintaining urban gardens and farms.

updates.text: Two months after the assembly, Douala City Council and Green Harvest Douala have identified five potential sites for urban agriculture. Community engagement sessions are planned to gather input and recruit volunteers. The initiative aims to establish the first two urban gardens within six months, improving local food access and security.

actions.text: Promote agroforestry practices that integrate tree planting with crop cultivation to restore degraded land, improve soil fertility, and enhance food production and biodiversity.

tasks.text: The community assembly participants can support the Green Roots Agroforestry Initiative by volunteering their time and skills, donating resources, and advocating for policies that encourage agroforestry practices.

updates.text: The Green Roots Agroforestry Initiative has planted over 1,000 trees on degraded farmland, with community volunteers contributing 500 hours. Soil fertility testing shows promising improvements. Local farmers are adopting agroforestry techniques, and the initiative is advocating for supportive policies. Fundraising efforts have secured donations to expand the program.

The Cameroon government, inspired by the community assembly's recommendation, has launched a nationwide agroforestry initiative. The program provides training and resources to farmers, encouraging the integration of diverse tree species into their croplands. Early reports indicate improved soil health and increased crop yields in participating regions.

actions.text: Establish a community-based seed bank to preserve local crop diversity and ensure access to resilient, adaptable seeds for farmers facing climate change impacts.

tasks.text: The Douala Community Seed Preservation Initiative (DCSPI) can collect, catalog, and store diverse local seed varieties in a secure facility, while providing education and access to these resilient seeds for farmers adapting to climate change.

updates.text: The DCSPI has collected over 100 local seed varieties, cataloged them, and begun distributing climate-resilient seeds to farmers. Educational workshops on seed saving and adaptive farming techniques have reached 50 farmers so far. The secure seed storage facility is now 75% complete, ensuring long-term preservation of crop diversity.

The community seed bank inspired neighboring villages to create their own, forming a regional network. This caught the attention of Cameroon's Ministry of Agriculture, which is now considering a national program to support local seed banks and promote climate-resilient crops, in line with the UN's global food security agenda.

actions.text: Advocate for global policies that prioritize food security and nutrition for vulnerable populations, particularly women and children, in trade agreements and climate change mitigation strategies.

target_actors.text: Global Alliance for Equitable Food Security (GAEFS)

tasks.text: Participants can write letters to their elected representatives and the leaders of GAEFS, urging them to prioritize food security for vulnerable populations in trade agreements and climate strategies.

updates.text: Two months after the assembly, over 150 participants have written letters to their elected officials and GAEFS leaders, calling for the prioritization of food security for women, children, and vulnerable populations in trade deals and climate plans. Several representatives have responded, expressing support and committing to address these concerns.

details.name: Kalimantan Timur Food Gathering
details.purpose: We are running this assembly to bring together diverse voices from Samarinda to discuss the challenges and opportunities around food in the face of climate change, deforestation, and biodiversity loss. By deliberating together, we hope to find locally-relevant solutions that can create a more sustainable and resilient future.
details.background: Samarinda, the capital of East Kalimantan, Indonesia, faces challenges related to food security and sustainability. The region's rapid deforestation for palm oil plantations and coal mining has led to biodiversity loss, soil degradation, and water pollution. These environmental issues, combined with the effects of climate change, threaten local food production and traditional farming practices. Additionally, the reliance on imported food and the increasing prevalence of processed foods contribute to health concerns. Addressing these interconnected problems requires a holistic approach that considers the social, economic, and ecological dimensions of food systems in Samarinda and beyond.
details.organisation_description: Pemerintah Kota Samarinda is the local government of Samarinda, the capital city of East Kalimantan province in Indonesia, responsible for administering urban services and development in the city.
details.supporters_description:
The Activist Network is supporting Pemerintah Kota Samarinda by organizing grassroots campaigns to raise awareness about local issues, such as environmental protection and sustainable development. They are mobilizing community members to participate in public hearings and provide input on city policies related to food security and resilience.

The Labor/Trade Union is collaborating with Pemerintah Kota Samarinda to ensure fair working conditions and wages for workers in the food industry, including farmers, food processors, and distributors. They are advocating for policies that support local food production and supply chains, while also protecting the rights and livelihoods of workers in the sector.
details.funders_description: The University of Mulawarman, based in Samarinda, is supporting the community assembly as part of its research initiative on sustainable food systems and their role in addressing regional environmental challenges. The university aims to gather insights from the assembly to inform its ongoing studies and contribute to policy recommendations for the local government.
details.recruitment_criteria: WHAT FORMAT? Setting demographic parameters? Living within a certain distance? Freeform text?

actions.text: Promote agroforestry practices that integrate food production with reforestation efforts to restore ecosystems, improve soil health, and enhance local livelihoods.

target_actors.text: Samarinda Agroforestry and Ecosystem Restoration Initiative (SAFERI)

tasks.text: Community assembly participants can support SAFERI's agroforestry projects by volunteering their time, sharing local knowledge, and advocating for policies that incentivize sustainable land management practices.

updates.text: Progress Update: SAFERI's agroforestry projects have gained momentum, with community volunteers planting over 1,000 trees and sharing valuable local knowledge. Participants have also advocated for supportive policies, resulting in increased government interest in incentivizing sustainable land management practices. The projects are well on their way to restoring ecosystems and enhancing livelihoods.

The Indonesian government has launched a nationwide agroforestry initiative, inspired by the community assembly's recommendations. The program provides funding and technical support to farmers adopting agroforestry practices, aiming to restore ecosystems and boost local economies. Other assemblies are exploring similar initiatives tailored to their regional contexts.

actions.text: Develop a comprehensive food education program that promotes healthy eating habits, traditional cooking methods, and the importance of consuming locally sourced, minimally processed foods.

target_actors.text: Yayasan Pendidikan Pangan Sehat Kalimantan Timur (YPPKT)

tasks.text: The community assembly participants could provide input on the key topics and target audiences for the food education program, and suggest ways to effectively engage the community in learning about healthy eating, traditional cooking, and the benefits of local, minimally processed foods.

updates.text: Six weeks post-assembly, a community-led task force has outlined a food education program focusing on healthy eating, traditional cooking, and local, minimally processed foods. Pilot workshops are being developed for various age groups, with input from local nutritionists, chefs, and farmers. The program is set to launch next quarter.

The Indonesian government, inspired by the community assembly's proposal, has launched a nationwide "Healthy Food, Healthy Nation" campaign. The initiative includes a comprehensive food education program in schools and community centers, emphasizing traditional cooking, local sourcing, and minimal processing. Other assemblies are now exploring similar programs in their regions.

actions.text: Establish a community-supported agriculture (CSA) program that connects local farmers with consumers to promote access to fresh, locally grown produce and support sustainable farming practices.

tasks.text: SSAN and Samarinda Sustainable Farm Share can collaborate to create a CSA program that allows consumers to purchase seasonal shares of locally grown produce directly from farmers, fostering a sustainable local food system.

updates.text: Progress Update: SSAN and Samarinda Sustainable Farm Share have launched a pilot CSA program with 50 members and 5 local farmers. Weekly produce deliveries have begun, and member feedback has been positive. Plans are underway to expand the program and recruit more farmers for the next growing season.

actions.text: Implement a community seed bank to preserve and share local crop varieties, ensuring food diversity and resilience in the face of climate change and environmental pressures.

tasks.text: The community assembly participants can support the Samarinda Community Seed Guardians by contributing local seed varieties, knowledge, and resources to establish and maintain a robust community seed bank.

updates.text: Two months after the assembly, the Samarinda Community Seed Guardians have collected over 50 local seed varieties from participants and community members. A suitable location for the seed bank has been identified, and volunteers are working to catalog the seeds and set up proper storage conditions to ensure their long-term viability.

actions.text: Advocate for policies that protect the land rights of indigenous communities, recognizing their role as stewards of biodiversity and traditional food systems.

target_actors.text: Gerakan Masyarakat Adat Kalimantan Timur untuk Kedaulatan Pangan (GMAKTKP)
Yayasan Penjaga Hutan Adat Kalimantan Timur (YPAKT)

tasks.text: Community assembly participants can support and amplify the advocacy efforts of GMAKTKP, KILDA, and YPAKT to influence policymakers to protect indigenous land rights and recognize their vital role in preserving biodiversity and traditional food systems.

updates.text: Progress Update: Our advocacy efforts with GMAKTKP, KILDA, and YPAKT have gained traction. We met with key policymakers to discuss protecting indigenous land rights, emphasizing their role in preserving biodiversity and traditional food systems. Two legislators have committed to sponsoring a bill addressing these issues. Next steps: draft bill language.

details.name: Bas-Sassandra Food Meeting
details.purpose: We are running this assembly to bring together our community in Sassandra to discuss the challenges we face with food security and sustainability. By deliberating together, we hope to find locally-relevant solutions that can help build a more resilient food system for the future of our region.
details.background: Sassandra, a coastal city in Bas-Sassandra, Cote d'Ivoire, faces challenges related to food security and sustainability. The region's economy heavily relies on agriculture, particularly cocoa production, which is vulnerable to climate change impacts. Deforestation and land degradation due to unsustainable farming practices are also concerns. The local fishing industry is affected by overfishing and pollution. Poverty and limited access to diverse, nutritious food sources are issues for many residents. The community assembly aims to address these interconnected problems and explore solutions that promote sustainable food systems and improve the well-being of Sassandra's population.
details.organisation_description: Sassandra Sustainable Development Initiative (SSDI) is a local NGO in Sassandra, Cote d'Ivoire, focused on promoting sustainable agriculture, environmental conservation, and community development projects in the Bas-Sassandra region.
details.supporters_description:
National Government: The government of Cote d'Ivoire provides funding for specific projects, facilitates necessary permits and approvals, and collaborates with SSDI to align their efforts with national development goals and strategies.

Individual: Local community members volunteer their time and skills to support SSDI's initiatives, participate in educational programs, and help raise awareness about sustainable development practices. Some individuals also make financial contributions to support the organization's work.
details.funders_description: The non-governmental organization "Sustainable Food Futures" is supporting a community assembly in Sassandra, Bas-Sassandra, Cote d'Ivoire, as part of their mission to promote food security and sustainable agricultural practices in developing countries. The organization recognizes the importance of engaging local communities in discussions about food systems and their role in addressing global challenges such as climate change, biodiversity loss, and social inequalities. By facilitating this assembly, the NGO aims to empower the people of Sassandra to develop locally-driven solutions that ensure access to nutritious food, support smallholder farmers, and foster resilient and environmentally-friendly food production methods. The NGO believes that community-led initiatives are crucial for creating lasting, positive change in the region's food landscape.
details.recruitment_criteria: WHAT FORMAT? Setting demographic parameters? Living within a certain distance? Freeform text?

actions.text: Promote agroforestry practices that integrate cocoa production with other crops and trees to improve soil health, biodiversity, and food security.

target_actors.text: Sassandra Agroforestry Initiative for Sustainable Cocoa (SAISC)
Sassandra Institute for Sustainable Agroforestry Research (SISAR)

tasks.text: The community assembly participants can support SACC, SAISC, and SISAR in their efforts to implement agroforestry practices that combine cocoa with other crops and trees, enhancing soil health, biodiversity, and food security in the region.

updates.text: Progress Update: SACC, SAISC, and SISAR have collaborated to establish 5 pilot agroforestry sites integrating cocoa with fruit trees and legumes. Initial soil tests show improved nutrient content and biodiversity. The organizations are now working to scale up the project and provide training to more local farmers.

The Ivorian government, inspired by the community assembly's recommendation, has launched a nationwide agroforestry program. It provides training and incentives for cocoa farmers to adopt practices that integrate shade trees and diverse crops. Early reports show improvements in soil health and biodiversity on participating farms.

actions.text: Establish community-managed marine protected areas to restore fish populations and promote sustainable fishing practices.

tasks.text: The community assembly participants could advocate for and support the establishment of community-managed marine protected areas by the Sassandra Municipal Council, Sassandra Sustainable Seas Initiative (SSSI) (a Community Based Organization), and Sassandra Sustainable Seas Initiative (SSSI) (a Non-Governmental Organization) to restore fish populations and promote sustainable fishing practices.

updates.text: Two months after the assembly, the Sassandra Municipal Council and SSSI have begun collaborating to designate potential marine protected areas. Community consultations are underway to gather input on boundaries and management. A draft proposal is expected next month, aiming to balance conservation with the needs of local fishers.

The Ivorian government, inspired by the community assembly's proposal, has partnered with local fishing communities to establish a network of marine protected areas along the coast. This initiative has garnered interest from other West African nations, who are considering similar collaborative approaches to promote sustainable fishing practices in the region.

actions.text: Develop a community-based program to promote composting and organic waste management, reducing food waste and improving soil fertility for urban gardens and local farms.

tasks.text: SOWS can organize workshops and provide resources to educate residents on composting techniques, establish community composting sites, and partner with local gardens and farms to utilize the compost.

updates.text: Two months after the assembly, SOWS has successfully launched a community composting program. Three workshops have been held, engaging over 100 residents. Two community composting sites are now operational, and partnerships with five urban gardens and three local farms have been established to utilize the nutrient-rich compost produced.

actions.text: Implement a community-based sustainable aquaculture project to provide an alternative protein source and reduce pressure on wild fish populations.

tasks.text: The community assembly participants can support the Sassandra Sustainable Aquaculture Cooperative (SSAC) and Sassandra Sustainable Aquaculture Initiative (SSAI) by providing resources, expertise, and advocacy to help establish and maintain a sustainable aquaculture project that benefits the local community and environment.

updates.text: The SSAC has secured a site and begun constructing ponds with community volunteers. SSAI is working with aquaculture experts to finalize species selection and sustainable feed sourcing. Outreach is underway to build local support. Next steps include finalizing permits, ordering fingerlings, and hosting an educational workshop for the community.

actions.text: Advocate for global policies that support small-scale farmers in transitioning to climate-resilient, diverse, and sustainable agricultural practices, ensuring food security for vulnerable communities worldwide.

target_actors.text: Global Alliance for Sustainable Agriculture and Food Security (GASAFS)

tasks.text: Community assembly participants can engage in letter-writing campaigns, online petitions, and peaceful demonstrations to urge GASAFS and SSAI to prioritize policies and initiatives that empower small-scale farmers to adopt climate-resilient, diverse, and sustainable practices, ensuring global food security.

updates.text: Two months after the assembly, over 10,000 signatures were collected through online petitions, and hundreds of letters were sent to GASAFS and SSAI representatives. Peaceful demonstrations were held in five major cities, raising awareness about the importance of supporting small-scale farmers in transitioning to sustainable practices for global food security.

The Ivorian government, inspired by the community assembly's recommendations, has partnered with international organizations to launch a comprehensive program supporting small-scale farmers in adopting sustainable practices. The initiative aims to enhance food security and climate resilience, with plans to share insights with other participating countries in the global assembly network.

details.name: Matabeleland North Food Conversation
details.purpose: We are running this assembly in Hwange to bring together diverse community members to deliberate on food security challenges and develop locally-driven solutions that address the impacts of climate change, biodiversity loss, and economic instability on our food systems, ensuring a more resilient and sustainable future for all.
details.background: Hwange, located in Matabeleland North, Zimbabwe, faces challenges related to food security due to droughts, land degradation, and economic instability. The region heavily relies on agriculture, with maize being the primary crop. Climate change has led to erratic rainfall patterns, affecting crop yields and livestock production. Limited access to modern farming techniques and resources exacerbates the situation. The global economic downturn has impacted the region's ability to import food, leading to higher prices and reduced accessibility. Addressing these interconnected issues requires a holistic approach that considers local context and global systemic challenges.
details.organisation_description: Hwange Community Development Trust is a grassroots organization in Matabeleland North, Zimbabwe, focused on sustainable agriculture, women's empowerment, and youth education to uplift the local community.
details.supporters_description:
National Government:
- Providing funding through grants for community development projects
- Offering technical assistance and expertise in areas such as agriculture and resource management
- Facilitating partnerships between the Hwange Community Development Trust and other relevant government agencies
- Supporting the development of infrastructure, such as roads and water systems, to improve the community's access to resources

Community Based Organization:
- Mobilizing local community members to actively participate in the Hwange Community Development Trust's initiatives
- Sharing local knowledge and expertise to ensure that projects are culturally appropriate and sustainable
- Volunteering time and labor to support the implementation of community development projects
- Acting as a liaison between the Hwange Community Development Trust and the local community to ensure effective communication and collaboration
details.funders_description: The Zimbabwe Electricity Supply Authority (ZESA), a government-owned corporation, is supporting a community assembly in Hwange, Matabeleland North, Zimbabwe, as part of its corporate social responsibility initiative. ZESA recognizes the importance of engaging local communities in discussions about sustainable food production and consumption, especially in the context of climate change and its impact on the region's energy sector. By sponsoring this assembly, ZESA aims to foster dialogue and collaboration between the community and the corporation, ultimately contributing to the development of more resilient and sustainable food systems in Hwange.
details.recruitment_criteria: WHAT FORMAT? Setting demographic parameters? Living within a certain distance? Freeform text?

actions.text: Develop a community-based seed bank to preserve and share drought-resistant, indigenous crop varieties adapted to local conditions.

tasks.text: Participants can support the Hwange Indigenous Seed Savers Collective in establishing a community seed bank by donating indigenous seeds, providing storage facilities, and volunteering their time and knowledge to help preserve and share the seeds.

updates.text: The Hwange Indigenous Seed Savers Collective has successfully established a community seed bank, thanks to generous seed donations and volunteer support. Over 20 indigenous crop varieties are now being preserved. The collective is working on expanding storage facilities and planning educational workshops to further promote local seed saving practices.

The community seed bank initiative has inspired three neighboring villages to start their own, forming a regional network. Zimbabwe's Ministry of Agriculture has taken notice and is considering a pilot program to support the establishment of community seed banks in drought-prone areas across the country.

actions.text: Implement a community-led agroforestry project to restore degraded land, improve soil fertility, and diversify food production.

tasks.text: The community assembly participants can support the Hwange Agroforestry Collective's agroforestry project by volunteering their time, sharing local knowledge, and helping to secure resources and funding.

updates.text: Two months on, the Hwange Agroforestry Collective has planted over 500 native trees on degraded land with the help of 30 community volunteers. Local farmers shared their knowledge of the area's ecology. A crowdfunding campaign has raised $2,000 to expand the project and purchase more saplings and tools.

The agroforestry project inspired neighboring communities to adopt similar practices. The network of assemblies successfully lobbied the Zimbabwean government to include agroforestry in its national climate adaptation plan, unlocking funding and technical support. The project's success was highlighted at a UN forum on nature-based solutions for food security.

actions.text: Establish a community-managed grazing system to prevent overgrazing, restore grasslands, and improve livestock health and productivity.

target_actors.text: Hwange Grassland Restoration and Livestock Management Association (HGRLMA)

tasks.text: The community assembly participants could support the HGRLMA in implementing a rotational grazing plan, building fences, monitoring grassland health, and educating local herders on sustainable livestock management practices.

updates.text: Two months after the assembly, the community has begun implementing a rotational grazing system. Fences have been built to divide pastures, and local herders are being trained on sustainable livestock management. The HGRLMA reports improved grassland health and increased livestock productivity. Regular monitoring is ongoing to ensure long-term success.

actions.text: Advocate for global climate finance mechanisms to support small-scale farmers in adapting to climate change and transitioning to sustainable, resilient agricultural practices.

target_actors.text: Global Alliance for Sustainable Agricultural Resilience (GASAR)

tasks.text: Community assembly participants can raise awareness about the importance of global climate finance mechanisms and put pressure on decision-makers to ensure that GASAR, GFRF, and Green Harvest Zimbabwe Foundation receive adequate funding and support to assist small-scale farmers in adapting to climate change and transitioning to sustainable agricultural practices.

updates.text:
Progress Update:
Our advocacy efforts have gained traction. We met with local representatives who pledged support for increased climate finance for small-scale farmers. A petition urging action from global leaders has gathered over 1,000 signatures. Next steps: continue raising awareness and engaging decision-makers to ensure funds reach GASAR, GFRF, and Green Harvest.

The Global Resilient Agriculture Fund, inspired by the community assembly's advocacy, has been established through the Green Climate Fund. It will provide $500 million in grants and low-interest loans to support small-scale farmers in Zimbabwe and other developing nations in adopting climate-smart farming practices and building resilience.

details.name: Saint Michael Climate Conversation
details.purpose: We are running this assembly to bring together diverse voices from Bridgetown to discuss the challenges and opportunities around food in the context of global crises. Our goal is to foster meaningful dialogue, build community, and generate ideas for local action to create a more resilient food system.
details.background: Bridgetown, the capital of Barbados, faces challenges related to food security and sustainability. As a small island nation, Barbados is vulnerable to climate change impacts, such as rising sea levels and more frequent hurricanes, which threaten local agriculture. The country relies heavily on imported food, making it susceptible to global food price fluctuations. Bridgetown's assembly aims to address these issues by promoting local food production, reducing food waste, and fostering community resilience in the face of global systemic challenges.
details.organisation_description: Bridgetown Community Empowerment Network is a grassroots organization in Bridgetown, Saint Michael, Barbados, focused on promoting social justice, education, and economic development through community-driven initiatives and partnerships.
details.supporters_description:
Philanthropic Organization: The Sandals Foundation, a non-profit organization based in the Caribbean, has provided a grant to the Bridgetown Community Empowerment Network to support their community outreach programs, focusing on education, health, and social welfare initiatives in Bridgetown, Saint Michael, Barbados.

National Government: The Ministry of People Empowerment and Elder Affairs of the Government of Barbados has partnered with the Bridgetown Community Empowerment Network to provide resources, expertise, and funding for community development projects, aiming to improve the quality of life for residents in Bridgetown, Saint Michael, Barbados.
details.funders_description: The University of the West Indies, Cave Hill Campus, is supporting the community assembly in Bridgetown, Saint Michael, Barbados as part of its research initiative on sustainable food systems and climate change adaptation in the Caribbean region. The university aims to engage with local communities, gather insights, and facilitate knowledge exchange to develop innovative solutions that address food security challenges in the face of global environmental crises.
details.recruitment_criteria: WHAT FORMAT? Setting demographic parameters? Living within a certain distance? Freeform text?

actions.text: Develop a community-based urban farming initiative to increase local food production and reduce dependence on imports.

tasks.text: Green Bridgetown Growers Association could provide training, resources, and land access to enable community members to start and maintain urban farms and gardens.

updates.text: Green Bridgetown Growers Association has launched its urban farming program, providing training to 50 community members so far. Three new urban farms have been established on unused land, with more sites being assessed. Participants are already harvesting their first crops, supplying fresh produce to local markets and families.

The urban farming initiative has inspired similar projects in community assemblies across the Caribbean. Participants are sharing knowledge and resources to scale up local food production. The Barbados government has taken notice and is considering policies to support urban agriculture as part of its national food security strategy.

actions.text: Establish a food waste reduction program in partnership with local restaurants, supermarkets, and schools to redirect surplus food to those in need.

tasks.text: BFRI and the City Council can collaborate to create a network of food donors, transportation logistics, storage facilities, and distribution points to efficiently rescue and redistribute surplus food to those facing food insecurity in the community.

updates.text: Progress Update: BFRI and the City Council have launched a pilot food waste reduction program with 5 local restaurants and 2 supermarkets. In the first month, 500 lbs of surplus food was rescued and redistributed to 3 community food banks, providing meals to over 200 individuals in need.

actions.text: Implement a community-wide composting program to reduce food waste and create nutrient-rich soil for local agriculture.

tasks.text: The community assembly participants could support the Green Barbados Composting Initiative (GBCI) in implementing a community-wide composting program by providing resources, spreading awareness, and participating in the program to reduce food waste and create nutrient-rich soil for local agriculture.

updates.text: Since the assembly, the GBCI has launched a pilot composting program in two neighborhoods. Over 50 households are now separating food waste for weekly collection. The nutrient-rich compost produced is being used in community gardens. Plans are underway to expand the program city-wide by year-end.

actions.text: Collaborate with Pacific Island nations to develop climate-resilient agricultural practices and share knowledge to protect vulnerable coastal communities from rising sea levels and extreme weather events.

tasks.text: The community assembly participants could advocate for increased funding and resources to support the collaboration between the Pacific-Caribbean Climate Resilience Partnership (PCCRP) and The Caribbean Climate Resilience Partnership (CCRP) in developing and implementing climate-resilient agricultural practices and knowledge-sharing initiatives to protect vulnerable coastal communities in the Pacific and Caribbean regions.

updates.text: The PCCRP and CCRP have initiated joint projects in Fiji and Jamaica to pilot climate-resilient farming techniques. Knowledge-sharing workshops are planned to engage coastal communities. Advocacy efforts have secured initial funding commitments from regional organizations to scale up these vital collaborations for protecting vulnerable Pacific and Caribbean communities.

The Barbados assembly's collaboration with Pacific Island nations has inspired similar partnerships worldwide. Assemblies in coastal regions are now actively sharing climate-resilient agricultural practices and advocating for global policies to support vulnerable communities. The UN has recognized these efforts and is considering a new fund for climate adaptation.

details.name: Potters Village Resilience Meeting
details.purpose: We're holding this assembly to bring our community together and discuss how we can build a more sustainable and resilient local food system in the face of global challenges. By sharing ideas and perspectives, we hope to find solutions that work for Potters Village and beyond.
details.background: Potters Village, a small community in Saint John, Antigua and Barbuda, faces challenges related to food security and sustainability. As an island nation, Antigua and Barbuda is vulnerable to the impacts of climate change, including rising sea levels and more frequent hurricanes, which threaten local agriculture. The community also grapples with the effects of globalization on food systems, such as dependence on imported processed foods and the erosion of traditional farming practices. The assembly aims to address these issues and explore solutions that promote resilience, self-sufficiency, and healthy food access for Potters Village residents.
details.organisation_description: Potters Village Environmental Justice Coalition is a grassroots activist network in Saint John, Antigua and Barbuda, advocating for sustainable development and environmental protection in the local community.
details.supporters_description:
Social Movement: The Antigua and Barbuda Youth Environmental Network (ABYEN) is collaborating with the Potters Village Environmental Justice Coalition by organizing awareness campaigns, community clean-up drives, and educational workshops to engage local residents in environmental conservation efforts.

Regional Government: The Ministry of Health, Wellness, and the Environment of Antigua and Barbuda is providing technical assistance and limited funding to the Potters Village Environmental Justice Coalition to support their initiatives in addressing environmental concerns and promoting sustainable practices within the community.
details.funders_description: The Caribbean Climate Justice Alliance, a regional activist network, is supporting the community assembly in Potters Village, Saint John, Antigua and Barbuda. They believe that empowering local communities to deliberate on food issues in the context of climate change is crucial for building resilience and advocating for equitable policies. By providing resources and expertise, the activist network aims to amplify the voices of marginalized communities and promote sustainable food systems in the face of interconnected planetary crises.
details.recruitment_criteria: WHAT FORMAT? Setting demographic parameters? Living within a certain distance? Freeform text?

actions.text: Establish a community seed bank to preserve and share local crop varieties adapted to the island's climate.

target_actors.text: Antigua and Barbuda Community Seed Savers (ABCSS)

tasks.text: The community assembly participants could support the establishment of the seed bank by volunteering their time, donating seeds, and spreading awareness about the importance of preserving local crop varieties.

updates.text: Two months after the assembly, volunteers have collected over 50 varieties of local seeds from farmers and gardeners. A suitable location for the seed bank has been identified, and renovations are underway. Outreach efforts have begun to educate the community about the seed bank's role in promoting resilient local agriculture.

actions.text: Develop a community-based composting program to create nutrient-rich soil for local gardens and farms, reducing waste and improving soil health.

tasks.text: The community assembly participants can support the collaboration between Potters Village Community Composting Initiative, Potters Village Council, and PVCCI to establish a composting program that engages residents in separating organic waste, which will be collected and processed into nutrient-rich compost for local gardens and farms.

updates.text: The Potters Village Community Composting Initiative has successfully launched, with over 100 households now separating organic waste. The Village Council and PVCCI have established a efficient collection system, and the first batch of nutrient-rich compost is ready for distribution to local gardens and farms, marking a significant step towards waste reduction and soil health improvement.

actions.text: Implement a community-supported agriculture (CSA) program to connect local farmers with consumers, ensuring a stable market for fresh, locally-grown produce.

tasks.text: The community assembly participants can support the Potters Village Farmers' Collective in establishing a CSA program by promoting the initiative, recruiting members, and providing resources to ensure its success.

updates.text: Two months after the assembly, the Potters Village Farmers' Collective has successfully launched its CSA program with 50 members. Community volunteers are helping with weekly produce distribution and member recruitment. The program is providing a stable market for local farmers and increasing access to fresh, healthy food for residents.

The CSA program has inspired similar initiatives in neighboring Caribbean islands, fostering regional food security.
