Feedback has been positive, with participants reporting increased knowledge and confidence in preparing nutritious meals for their families.

actions.text: Establish a food reserve system to buffer against supply chain disruptions and ensure food availability during crises.

tasks.text: The community assembly participants could advocate for collaboration between the Nauru National Food Security Agency, Nauru Food Security Council, and Yaren District Council to create a comprehensive food reserve system with clear roles and responsibilities at each level of government.

updates.text: Two months post-assembly, the Nauru National Food Security Agency has initiated discussions with the Nauru Food Security Council and Yaren District Council to develop a collaborative food reserve system. Preliminary plans outline storage facilities, inventory management, and distribution protocols. Further meetings are scheduled to finalize roles and responsibilities.

The Nauruan government, inspired by the community assembly's proposal, has partnered with neighboring Pacific island nations to create a regional food reserve network. This collaborative effort aims to enhance food security and resilience across the region, enabling swift support and resource sharing during future supply chain disruptions or crises.

actions.text: Implement policies to support local food businesses and entrepreneurs in developing innovative, sustainable, and culturally appropriate food products using indigenous ingredients and traditional knowledge.

tasks.text: The community assembly participants could advocate for and help secure funding, resources, and partnerships to enable NIFI to work with the Yaren District Council at both local and regional levels to develop policies that foster the growth of local, sustainable food businesses drawing on traditional Nauruan ingredients and knowledge.

updates.text:
Progress Update:
NIFI has partnered with the Yaren District Council to secure initial funding for a pilot program supporting local food entrepreneurs. Three businesses have been selected to receive grants, training, and mentorship to develop sustainable products using traditional Nauruan ingredients. Policy recommendations are being drafted based on the program's early successes.

The Nauruan government has partnered with community assemblies to launch a grant program supporting local food businesses that utilize indigenous ingredients and traditional knowledge. This initiative has sparked collaboration between entrepreneurs across the island nation, fostering innovation in sustainable and culturally appropriate food products.

actions.text: Develop a sustainable food waste management system to reduce environmental impact and explore opportunities for composting and food redistribution to those in need.

tasks.text: The community assembly participants could advocate for and support the Yaren District Council in implementing a comprehensive food waste reduction program that includes composting initiatives and partnerships with local organizations to redistribute surplus food to those facing food insecurity.

updates.text:
Progress Update:
The Yaren District Council has begun drafting a sustainable food waste management plan. Discussions are underway with local NGOs to establish food redistribution networks. A pilot composting project has been launched in partnership with a community garden, with plans to expand the program in the coming months.

The Nauru government, inspired by the community assembly's proposal, has partnered with local NGOs to establish a nationwide food waste reduction and redistribution program. This initiative has caught the attention of other Pacific island nations, who are now considering implementing similar programs to address food insecurity and environmental sustainability.

actions.text: Collaborate with other Pacific Island nations to advocate for climate action and support for adaptation measures to protect food security and livelihoods of vulnerable communities.

target_actors.text: Nauru Pacific Islands Climate Action Coalition (NPICAC)

tasks.text: Participants could encourage their government representatives to actively engage with NPICAC and PICRA to develop a unified Pacific voice on climate action and adaptation strategies to safeguard regional food security and livelihoods.

updates.text:
Progress Update:
Our nation has joined forces with NPICAC and PICRA, actively participating in regional dialogues to develop a shared Pacific stance on climate action. Collaborative efforts are underway to secure international support for adaptation measures that will protect food security and livelihoods across our vulnerable island communities.

details.name: George Town Food Meeting
details.purpose: We are running this assembly to bring together diverse voices from our community to discuss the challenges and opportunities around food in the context of global crises. By deliberating together, we hope to find local solutions that can contribute to a more sustainable and resilient food future for all.
details.background: George Town, the capital of the Cayman Islands, faces food security challenges due to its heavy reliance on imports, limited agricultural land, and vulnerability to climate change impacts such as rising sea levels and more frequent hurricanes. As a small island nation, the Cayman Islands are particularly susceptible to global economic fluctuations and supply chain disruptions, which can affect food availability and prices. Addressing these issues requires a focus on sustainable local food production, resilient infrastructure, and international cooperation to mitigate the effects of climate change and ensure stable food supplies in the face of global crises.
details.organisation_description: Cayman Islands Sustainable Food Initiative (CISFI) is a non-profit organization based in George Town, promoting local food production, sustainable agriculture, and food security across the Cayman Islands.
details.supporters_description:
Philanthropic Organization: The Cayman Islands Community Foundation, a local philanthropic organization, has provided a substantial grant to support CISFI's community garden project, which aims to promote sustainable food production and improve access to fresh, locally grown produce for residents of George Town.

Individual: Liam Thompson, a retired businessman and long-time resident of George Town, has been volunteering his time and expertise to help CISFI develop a comprehensive strategic plan for their initiatives. He also regularly participates in community outreach events to raise awareness about sustainable food practices and the importance of supporting local food systems.
details.funders_description: The Cayman Islands Farmers' Cooperative, a community-based organization, is supporting the community assembly in George Town, Grand Cayman, to discuss the challenges faced by local farmers and explore innovative solutions to promote sustainable agriculture practices, enhance food security, and strengthen the local food system in the face of climate change and economic uncertainties.
details.recruitment_criteria: WHAT FORMAT? Setting demographic parameters? Living within a certain distance? Freeform text?

actions.text: Develop a comprehensive plan to increase local food production through sustainable agriculture practices, urban gardening initiatives, and community-supported agriculture programs.

tasks.text: The community assembly participants could advocate for and support collaboration between the George Town Municipal Council, Cayman Islands Sustainable Food Network (CISFN), and Cayman Sustainable Food Initiative (CSFI) to create a detailed roadmap for boosting local, sustainable food production through a multi-pronged approach involving eco-friendly farming, urban gardens, and community-supported agriculture schemes.

updates.text: Progress Update: The George Town Municipal Council has partnered with CISFN and CSFI to draft a sustainable local food production plan. Pilot projects for urban gardens and community-supported agriculture have launched. Next steps include securing funding, identifying land for eco-friendly farms, and engaging more community members to participate.

The Cayman Islands government has allocated funds to support the assembly's local food production plan, inspired by similar initiatives in other countries. The global network of assemblies is collaborating to share best practices and resources, aiming to enhance food security and sustainability worldwide.

actions.text: Establish a food waste reduction and redistribution program to divert surplus food from landfills to those in need, improving food security and sustainability.

tasks.text: The community assembly participants could support the collaboration between CFRI and CIFRA to create an efficient system for collecting surplus food from businesses and distributing it to food-insecure individuals and families.

updates.text: Progress Update: CFRI and CIFRA have partnered to launch a pilot food redistribution program. In the first month, 10 local businesses donated surplus food, which was delivered to 50 food-insecure households. The program aims to expand to more businesses and recipients in the coming months, reducing waste and hunger.

actions.text: Collaborate with other small island nations to advocate for stronger international commitments to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and provide climate adaptation funding for vulnerable communities.

target_actors.text: Cayman Islands Ministry of Sustainability and Climate Resilience

tasks.text: The community assembly participants could write letters to their elected representatives and the leaders of CCAA, CICAC, and the Cayman Islands Ministry of Sustainability and Climate Resilience, urging them to prioritize collaboration with other small island nations on advocating for stronger international climate commitments and adaptation funding.

updates.text: Since the assembly, our community has sent over 200 letters to elected officials and key ministries, urging collaboration with other island nations on climate action. The Ministry of Sustainability and Climate Resilience has responded, committing to raise these issues at the upcoming Island States Climate Summit in partnership with CCAA and CICAC.

details.name: Encarnación Food Gathering
details.purpose: We are holding this assembly to engage our community in a dialogue about the challenges facing our local food system and to collectively explore sustainable solutions that can enhance food security, support local producers, and promote a more resilient and equitable food future for Encarnación and the surrounding region.
details.background: Encarnación, a city in southern Paraguay, faces challenges related to food security and sustainability. As an agricultural region, Itapúa is vulnerable to climate change impacts, such as droughts and floods, affecting crop yields. Poverty and inequality also contribute to food insecurity for many residents. The city's proximity to the Paraná River and its biodiversity are threatened by deforestation and land use changes. Addressing these interconnected issues requires local action and global cooperation to build a more resilient and equitable food system in Encarnación and beyond.
details.organisation_description: Fundación Yvy Porã is a grassroots NGO in Encarnación, Paraguay, promoting sustainable agriculture, food security, and community empowerment through education, training, and collaborative projects with local farmers and indigenous communities.
details.supporters_description:
Regional Government: The regional government of Itapúa provides funding for Fundación Yvy Porã's projects and initiatives, as well as logistical support and access to public spaces for events and meetings. The government also collaborates with the NGO to develop policies and strategies that align with the organization's mission of promoting sustainable food practices and addressing planetary crises.

Social Movement: A grassroots social movement in Encarnación, focused on environmental justice and sustainable agriculture, actively supports Fundación Yvy Porã by mobilizing community members to participate in the NGO's events, workshops, and campaigns. The movement also shares resources, knowledge, and networks with the organization, helping to amplify its message and expand its reach within the local community.
details.funders_description: The non-governmental organization "Sustainable Food Futures" is supporting a community assembly in Encarnación, Itapúa, Paraguay as part of their global initiative to promote local food systems and sustainable agriculture practices. The organization recognizes the importance of engaging communities in discussions about food security, environmental conservation, and economic resilience in the face of climate change and other planetary crises. By facilitating this assembly, they aim to empower local stakeholders to develop context-specific solutions and foster collaboration between farmers, consumers, and policymakers in the region.
details.recruitment_criteria: WHAT FORMAT? Setting demographic parameters? Living within a certain distance? Freeform text?

actions.text: Promote agroforestry practices that integrate native tree species with crops to improve soil health, biodiversity, and resilience to climate change.

target_actors.text: Asociación de Agroforestería Nativa de Itapúa (AANI)

tasks.text: The community assembly participants can support AANI in implementing agroforestry projects by providing volunteer labor, sharing local knowledge about native tree species, and advocating for policies that incentivize agroforestry adoption among farmers.

updates.text: Progress Update: AANI has partnered with local farmers to plant over 500 native trees integrated with crops on 50 acres of land. Community volunteers have contributed 200+ hours of labor and shared valuable knowledge. AANI is now working with policymakers to develop incentives for wider agroforestry adoption.

The Paraguayan government, inspired by the community assembly's recommendation, has launched a nationwide agroforestry initiative. The program provides funding and technical support to farmers who integrate native tree species into their crop systems, aiming to improve soil health, biodiversity, and climate resilience. Other assemblies are considering similar proposals.

actions.text: Establish community seed banks to preserve and share diverse, locally-adapted crop varieties that are more resilient to climate change impacts.

target_actors.text: Instituto de Agrobiodiversidad y Desarrollo Sostenible de Itapúa (IADSI)

tasks.text: Participants can support SRE and IADSI in setting up seed banks by donating seeds, providing storage space, and volunteering their time and knowledge to help collect, catalog, and distribute diverse crop varieties.

updates.text: Two months after the assembly, SRE and IADSI have received seed donations from over 50 local farmers. Volunteers have begun cataloging the varieties and setting up a storage facility donated by the community center. The first seed distribution event is planned for next month to share these climate-resilient crops.

The Paraguayan government, inspired by the community assembly's proposal, has launched a national initiative to support the establishment of community seed banks. The program provides funding and technical assistance to help communities preserve and share diverse, locally-adapted crop varieties, enhancing food security and resilience to climate change.

actions.text: Develop a community-based composting program to reduce food waste, improve soil fertility, and promote sustainable urban agriculture.

tasks.text: The community assembly participants can support the development of a community-based composting program by volunteering their time, donating resources, and advocating for the collaboration between Composta Encarnación and the Municipalidad de Encarnación to ensure the program's success and sustainability.

updates.text: Two months after the assembly, Composta Encarnación and the Municipalidad de Encarnación have established a partnership. Volunteers have begun collecting food waste from local households and businesses. The first batch of compost is expected in 6 weeks, which will be used to support urban agriculture initiatives.

actions.text: Implement a community-led river conservation program to protect the Paraná River's biodiversity and promote sustainable fishing practices, ensuring food security for local communities.

target_actors.text: Asociación Itapúa para la Conservación del Río Paraná (AICORP)

tasks.text: The community assembly participants can support AICORP's efforts by volunteering their time, sharing local knowledge, and advocating for government funding and policies that enable the successful implementation of the Paraná River conservation program.

updates.text: Two months after the assembly, AICORP has trained 25 community volunteers in sustainable fishing practices and river conservation. Regular river clean-ups have begun, and the team is collecting data on fish populations. Meetings with local officials are underway to secure funding and policy support for the long-term program.

The Paraná River conservation program, initiated by the community assembly, has inspired similar initiatives along the river's course in Brazil and Argentina. These coordinated efforts have led to the establishment of a trilateral agreement between the countries to protect the river's biodiversity and support sustainable fishing practices across borders.

actions.text: Collaborate with indigenous communities in the Amazon to share traditional knowledge on sustainable food production and forest management, promoting cultural exchange and global solidarity.

tasks.text: AIAE and Raíces Amazónicas Paraguay can organize knowledge-sharing workshops and cultural exchange programs between indigenous Amazonian communities and other regions to promote sustainable food practices and forest stewardship.

updates.text:
Progress Update:
AIAE and Raíces Amazónicas Paraguay have conducted two successful knowledge-sharing workshops with indigenous Amazonian communities. Participants exchanged insights on sustainable food production and forest management. Plans are underway for a cultural exchange program to foster global solidarity and promote the adoption of these practices in other regions.

details.name: Petite-Terre Food Assembly
details.purpose: We are holding this assembly in Pamandzi to bring together our diverse community and collectively explore how we can build a more sustainable and resilient local food system, in the face of global challenges. By sharing ideas and perspectives, we hope to find solutions that work for everyone.
details.background: Pamandzi, located on Petite-Terre island in Mayotte, faces challenges related to food security and sustainability. As a French overseas department, it relies heavily on imported food, making it vulnerable to global supply chain disruptions. The island's limited agricultural land and growing population put pressure on local food production. Climate change impacts, such as rising sea levels and extreme weather events, threaten the island's fragile ecosystem and food resources. Addressing these interconnected issues requires a collaborative effort to promote sustainable local food systems, reduce dependence on imports, and build resilience against global crises.
details.organisation_description: Commune de Pamandzi is the local government of Pamandzi, a town on Petite-Terre island in the French overseas department of Mayotte, located in the Indian Ocean off East Africa.
details.supporters_description:
The Commune de Pamandzi in Pamandzi, Petite-Terre, Mayotte is supported by:

1. Local Government: The Commune de Pamandzi receives financial support, resources, and administrative assistance from the local government of Mayotte. This includes funding for infrastructure projects, public services, and community development initiatives.

2. Government-Owned Corporation: A government-owned corporation, such as a public utility company or a state-owned enterprise, provides services and resources to the Commune de Pamandzi. This may include water and electricity supply, waste management, or transportation services, which contribute to the overall functioning and development of the commune.
details.funders_description: The social movement "Mayotte Food Sovereignty" is supporting the community assembly in Pamandzi, Petite-Terre, Mayotte, as part of their campaign to promote local, sustainable food systems and reduce the island's dependence on imported food. The movement believes that empowering communities to make decisions about their food supply is crucial for achieving food security and resilience in the face of climate change and economic instability.
details.recruitment_criteria: WHAT FORMAT? Setting demographic parameters? Living within a certain distance? Freeform text?

actions.text: Develop a comprehensive plan to increase local food production through sustainable agricultural practices, community gardens, and support for small-scale farmers.

target_actors.text: Pamandzi Municipal Council for Sustainable Agriculture and Food Security
Conseil Régional de Mayotte (Regional Council of Mayotte)

tasks.text: The community assembly participants could advocate for increased funding, resources, and policy support from the Pamandzi Municipal Council for Sustainable Agriculture and Food Security, Mayotte Sustainable Agriculture Network (MSAN), and Conseil Régional de Mayotte to develop and implement a comprehensive plan promoting local, sustainable food production through community gardens, small-scale farmer support, and eco-friendly agricultural practices.

updates.text: 37 community gardens established; 12 small-scale farmers received grants. MSAN conducted 5 sustainable agriculture workshops. Pamandzi Council passed ordinance rezoning land for urban agriculture. Comprehensive plan drafted, under review by stakeholders. Implementation to begin next quarter, pending Conseil Régional approval of funding request.

actions.text: Establish a food waste reduction and redistribution program to address food insecurity and minimize environmental impact.

tasks.text: The community assembly participants can support the Mayotte Food Rescue Initiative (MFRI) in implementing a comprehensive food waste reduction and redistribution program by providing resources, expertise, and community outreach to ensure its success in tackling food insecurity and reducing environmental impact.

updates.text: The MFRI has launched its food waste reduction program, partnering with local restaurants and supermarkets. Over 500kg of surplus food has been redistributed to community members in need. Educational campaigns on food waste are underway, and plans are being developed to expand the program's reach and impact.

The Mayotte assembly's food waste reduction program has inspired similar initiatives in other communities worldwide. The UN Food and Agriculture Organization has taken notice and is developing guidelines based on Mayotte's model to help countries implement national food waste reduction and redistribution strategies, promoting food security and sustainability globally.

actions.text: Develop an educational campaign to raise awareness about the importance of supporting local, sustainable food systems and reducing reliance on imported food.

tasks.text: MSFEI could create engaging educational materials and host community events to inform residents about the benefits of local, sustainable food and provide practical tips for shifting purchasing habits.

updates.text: Progress Update: MSFEI launched an educational campaign with a series of informative brochures and hosted two well-attended community workshops on supporting local, sustainable food. Participants learned about the benefits and received practical tips for shifting their purchasing habits. Planning is underway for additional events to further raise awareness.

The educational campaign inspired similar initiatives in other community assemblies across Mayotte. This collective effort caught the attention of the national government, which has now pledged to increase funding for local, sustainable agriculture and reduce import subsidies, marking a significant shift towards food self-sufficiency for the island.

actions.text: Collaborate with other small island nations to advocate for climate change mitigation and adaptation measures that protect food security and biodiversity.

target_actors.text: Mayotte Island Alliance for Climate Action (MIACA)

tasks.text: GIFRA, MIACA, and MICRA can jointly develop a strategic plan to lobby for climate policies that safeguard food systems and ecosystems in small island nations.

updates.text: Two months after the assembly, GIFRA, MIACA, and MICRA have formed a coalition and drafted a joint strategic plan. They are currently engaging with key stakeholders and policymakers to advocate for climate policies that prioritize food security and biodiversity conservation in small island nations.

details.name: Jakar Food Meeting
details.purpose: We are organizing this assembly in Jakar to bring together diverse voices from our community to discuss the challenges and opportunities around food security, sustainability, and resilience in the face of global crises. By deliberating together, we hope to find locally-relevant solutions that strengthen our food systems.
details.background: Jakar, the heart of Bhutan's agricultural region, faces challenges in maintaining food security amidst climate change. Traditional farming practices are threatened by erratic weather patterns and soil degradation. As a remote mountain community, Jakar is vulnerable to disruptions in food supply chains caused by global crises. The assembly aims to address these issues by fostering dialogue among local farmers, policymakers, and experts to develop sustainable solutions that preserve Bhutan's unique agro-ecological heritage while ensuring long-term food resilience in the face of global uncertainties.
details.organisation_description: Bumthang Food Justice Coalition is a grassroots activist network in Jakar, Bhutan, advocating for sustainable agriculture, equitable access to nutritious food, and supporting local farmers and food producers.
details.supporters_description:
The Bumthang Food Justice Coalition in Jakar, Bumthang, Bhutan is supported by:

Labor/Trade Union: The Bhutan Agriculture and Food Workers' Union (BAFWU) collaborates with the Bumthang Food Justice Coalition by advocating for fair wages, safe working conditions, and sustainable practices in the local food industry. BAFWU also helps organize educational workshops and training sessions for workers to promote food justice principles.

Community Based Organization: The Jakar Community Development Association (JCDA) partners with the Bumthang Food Justice Coalition to engage local residents in the movement. JCDA facilitates community meetings, helps distribute resources and information, and works to build a strong network of support for the coalition's initiatives within the Jakar community.
details.funders_description: The Bhutan Power Corporation, a government-owned utility company, is supporting the community assembly in Jakar, Bumthang, as part of its corporate social responsibility initiative. The corporation recognizes the importance of engaging local communities in discussions about sustainable food systems and their role in addressing the interconnected planetary crises. By providing financial support and resources, the Bhutan Power Corporation aims to facilitate a meaningful dialogue and contribute to the development of resilient and environmentally-friendly food practices in the region.
details.recruitment_criteria: WHAT FORMAT? Setting demographic parameters? Living within a certain distance? Freeform text?

actions.text: Promote agroforestry practices that integrate tree planting with crop cultivation to improve soil health, enhance biodiversity, and increase resilience against climate change impacts.

target_actors.text: Bhutan Agroforestry and Sustainable Landscapes Initiative (BASLI)

tasks.text: Community assembly participants can support the collaboration between BARI, BASLI, and the Bumthang Agroforestry Alliance to implement agroforestry projects, share knowledge, and advocate for policies that promote sustainable land management practices in Bumthang.

updates.text: The Bumthang Agroforestry Alliance, in collaboration with BARI and BASLI, has successfully initiated three pilot agroforestry projects. Over 500 trees have been planted alongside crops, with plans to expand the project and conduct workshops to share knowledge and best practices with local farmers in the coming months.

actions.text: Establish a community seed bank to preserve and share diverse, locally-adapted crop varieties that are resilient to climate change and ensure long-term food security.

tasks.text: The Bumthang Community Seed Guardians can collect, store, and distribute a wide range of locally-adapted, climate-resilient seeds to farmers in the community, ensuring the preservation of crop diversity and long-term food security.

updates.text: The Bumthang Community Seed Bank is now operational, with over 50 local farmers contributing diverse seed varieties. We have collected and stored seeds from 20 resilient crop types so far. Distribution to farmers will begin next month, promoting sustainable agriculture and food security in our community.

The community seed bank inspired neighboring villages to create their own, forming a regional network. This caught the attention of Bhutan's Ministry of Agriculture, which is now considering a national program to support community seed banks as part of its climate change adaptation and food security strategy.

actions.text: Develop partnerships with mountain communities worldwide to exchange knowledge on climate-resilient farming practices and strengthen global solidarity in the face of food system challenges.

target_actors.text: Bhutan Mountain Farmers' Alliance for Climate Resilience (BMFACR)

tasks.text: IMFRN and BMFACR could collaborate to facilitate knowledge-sharing workshops and farmer exchanges between mountain communities, fostering the adoption of climate-resilient agricultural techniques and building a supportive global network.

updates.text:
Progress Update:
IMFRN and BMFACR have initiated dialogues with mountain communities in Nepal, Peru, and Italy to plan knowledge-sharing workshops. A virtual platform is being developed to enable ongoing farmer exchanges. Funding proposals have been submitted to support in-person visits and the implementation of climate-resilient farming practices.

The Bhutanese assembly has connected with mountain communities in Peru and Nepal, sharing their knowledge on climate-resilient farming. This global network is now advocating for the inclusion of mountain perspectives in the upcoming UN Food Systems Summit, aiming to shape policies that support sustainable and resilient food systems worldwide.

details.name: Apetina Community Gathering
details.purpose: We are running this assembly in Apetina to bring together our diverse community to discuss the challenges and opportunities around food in the context of global crises. By deliberating together, we hope to find local solutions that can contribute to a more sustainable and resilient future for all.
details.background: Apetina, a remote Trio village in Sipaliwini, Suriname, faces challenges in maintaining traditional food practices amidst global pressures. Deforestation and climate change threaten the rainforest, impacting hunting and gathering. Increased reliance on imported processed foods is linked to health issues. The community seeks to preserve their cultural heritage and ensure food security by promoting sustainable agriculture, protecting biodiversity, and advocating for their rights in the face of extractive industries. Strengthening local food systems and indigenous knowledge is crucial for resilience in the interconnected global food crisis.
details.organisation_description: Stichting Apetina Gemeenschap Ontwikkeling (AGO) is a community-based organization in Apetina, Sipaliwini, Suriname, focused on sustainable development, cultural preservation, and empowering the local Wayana indigenous community through education and economic initiatives.
details.supporters_description:
Individual supporters are making regular financial contributions to Stichting Apetina Gemeenschap Ontwikkeling (AGO) to help fund their community development projects in Apetina. Some individuals are also volunteering their time and skills to assist with specific initiatives.

An activist network focused on indigenous rights and environmental protection in the Amazon region is partnering with AGO to raise awareness about the challenges faced by the Apetina community. The network is organizing fundraising events, petition drives, and social media campaigns to garner support for AGO's work. Additionally, the activist network is providing AGO with access to their contacts and resources to help expand their reach and impact.
details.funders_description: The Inter-Religious Council of Suriname, a faith-based organization promoting interfaith dialogue and cooperation, is supporting the community assembly in Apetina, Sipaliwini, Suriname. They believe that addressing food security and sustainability issues in the context of global crises requires the collective wisdom and unity of diverse religious communities. By facilitating the assembly, they aim to foster understanding, share insights from various faith traditions, and encourage collaborative action to build a more resilient and equitable food system in the region.
details.recruitment_criteria: WHAT FORMAT? Setting demographic parameters? Living within a certain distance? Freeform text?

actions.text: Establish a community seed bank to preserve traditional crop varieties and promote food sovereignty.

tasks.text: The community assembly participants could support the Apetina Traditional Seed Keepers Collective and Apetina Traditional Seed Keepers in establishing a community seed bank by providing resources, expertise, and volunteers to help collect, catalog, and preserve traditional crop varieties.

updates.text: The Apetina Seed Keepers have collected over 100 traditional crop varieties for the new community seed bank. Volunteers are helping to catalog and preserve the seeds. The collective is planning workshops to share knowledge about growing these crops and promote food sovereignty in the community.

The Suriname community seed bank, inspired by the assembly, has partnered with a global network of seed savers to exchange knowledge and resources. This collaboration has led to the preservation of over 100 traditional crop varieties and the development of a national policy supporting local food systems and biodiversity.

actions.text: Develop a community-based agroforestry program that integrates traditional knowledge with sustainable land management practices to restore degraded areas and enhance food security.

tasks.text: The community assembly participants can support the Apetina Agroforestry Collective by sharing their traditional knowledge, volunteering their time and skills, and advocating for resources and partnerships to implement the agroforestry program effectively.

updates.text: The Apetina Agroforestry Collective has begun restoring 10 hectares of degraded land using traditional techniques shared by community elders. Thirty volunteers have planted over 500 native fruit and timber trees. The collective is now seeking partnerships with local NGOs to scale up the program and enhance food security.

actions.text: Create a community-led monitoring system to track changes in biodiversity, hunting patterns, and food availability to inform adaptive management strategies.

target_actors.text: Apetina Biodiversity and Food Security Monitoring Initiative (ABFSMI)

tasks.text: ABFSMI can establish a participatory monitoring program where trained community members regularly collect data on key indicators of biodiversity, hunting activities, and food availability to guide adaptive management decisions.

updates.text: Two months post-assembly, ABFSMI has trained 15 community members in biodiversity monitoring techniques. Participants have begun collecting baseline data on species abundance, hunting rates, and seasonal food availability in local forests and markets. This initial data is being compiled to inform the development of adaptive management plans.

The community-led monitoring system has been adopted by three neighboring villages, expanding the data collection network. Preliminary findings were presented at a national conference on sustainable wildlife management, catching the attention of Suriname's Ministry of Spatial Planning and Environment, which is considering integrating community-generated data into national biodiversity strategies.

actions.text: Establish a community-based ecotourism program that showcases traditional food practices and generates income for conservation and sustainable development initiatives.

target_actors.text: Apetina Sustainable Ecotourism and Traditional Foods Initiative (ASETFI)
Apetina Sustainable Ecotourism and Traditional Foods Initiative (ASETFI)

tasks.text: The community assembly participants could provide input on the design of the ecotourism program, identify key traditional food practices to showcase, and suggest ways to allocate the generated income to support conservation and sustainable development projects.

updates.text: Progress update: The community has identified three traditional food practices to showcase in the ecotourism program. A committee has been formed to design the program and allocate funds. Meetings with local conservation groups are underway to discuss potential projects. A pilot tour is planned for next month.

actions.text: Advocate for the rights of indigenous communities in global climate negotiations to protect their traditional lands, food systems, and cultural heritage from the impacts of extractive industries.

tasks.text: The community assembly participants could support and amplify the advocacy efforts of the Apetina Indigenous Climate Justice Alliance and Apetina Indigenous Climate Advocacy Network (AICAN) to protect indigenous rights, lands, food systems, and cultural heritage in global climate negotiations.

updates.text: Progress Update: AICAN representatives attended COP27, advocating for indigenous rights and presenting their sustainable food systems as climate solutions. The assembly participants launched a letter-writing campaign to support AICAN's demands, and are planning a fundraiser to help cover travel costs for indigenous leaders to participate in future negotiations.

Indigenous leaders from Suriname, backed by a global network of community assemblies, successfully lobbied for the inclusion of protections for indigenous food systems and land rights in the latest UN climate agreement, setting a precedent for future negotiations and bolstering efforts to resist extractive industries on traditional territories.

details.name: Limerick Community Assembly
details.purpose: We're running this assembly to bring together diverse voices from Limerick and discuss how we can create a more sustainable and equitable food system for our community, considering the global challenges we face. By deliberating together, we hope to find local solutions that promote resilience and well-being.
details.background: Limerick, a city in Ireland's Munster province, faces challenges related to food security and sustainability. As a regional hub, Limerick grapples with the impacts of climate change on agriculture, the need for sustainable food production, and ensuring access to nutritious food for its growing population. The city also recognizes its role in addressing global issues such as reducing food waste, supporting local farmers, and promoting sustainable consumption habits. Limerick's assembly aims to foster dialogue and action to build a resilient and equitable food system, both locally and as part of the global community.
details.organisation_description: The Limerick Community Foundation is a charitable organization dedicated to improving the lives of Limerick residents through grants, scholarships, and community initiatives focused on education, health, and social welfare.
details.supporters_description:
Non-Governmental Organization: The Munster Food Security Alliance, a regional NGO focused on addressing food insecurity, is partnering with The Limerick Community Foundation to provide funding for local food banks, community gardens, and educational programs on sustainable agriculture and healthy eating habits.

Individual: Siobhan O'Connor, a local business owner and philanthropist, has pledged a significant donation to The Limerick Community Foundation to support their initiatives in addressing food-related issues in the community. She is also volunteering her time and expertise to help the foundation develop strategic partnerships and raise awareness about their cause.
details.funders_description: The Limerick Food Partnership, a community-based organization dedicated to promoting sustainable food systems and food security in Limerick, is supporting the community assembly as part of their mission to engage local residents in shaping the future of food in their city. They believe that the assembly will provide a platform for diverse voices to be heard and will contribute to the development of a more resilient and equitable food system in Limerick.
details.recruitment_criteria: WHAT FORMAT? Setting demographic parameters? Living within a certain distance? Freeform text?

actions.text: Develop a comprehensive urban agriculture program to increase local food production and improve access to fresh, nutritious produce for Limerick residents.

tasks.text: Participants could advocate for the allocation of public land, funding, and resources to support the establishment of community gardens, rooftop gardens, and other urban agriculture initiatives throughout Limerick.

updates.text:
Progress Update:
The Limerick City Council has allocated land for 5 new community gardens and provided funding for a pilot rooftop garden program. A task force has been formed to oversee the implementation and engage with local communities. The first garden is set to open next month, with more to follow.

The Limerick urban agriculture program has inspired similar initiatives in Dublin and Cork. The Irish government has taken notice and is considering a national policy to support urban farming, with input from the Limerick assembly. Global networks are sharing the Limerick model as a promising local food solution.

actions.text: Establish a food waste reduction education campaign targeting households, businesses, and institutions in Limerick.

tasks.text: Participants could support the food waste reduction education campaign by volunteering to help Limerick City and County Council and Limerick Food Waste Warriors develop and disseminate engaging educational materials tailored to households, businesses, and institutions.

updates.text: Two months after the assembly, Limerick City and County Council, in collaboration with Limerick Food Waste Warriors and local volunteers, has developed a comprehensive set of educational materials on food waste reduction. The campaign is set to launch next month, targeting households, businesses, and institutions across Limerick.

The Limerick food waste reduction campaign has inspired similar initiatives in Dublin and Cork. Ireland's government is now considering nationwide legislation to mandate food waste reduction targets and reporting for large businesses and institutions, aiming to halve the country's food waste by 2030 in line with UN sustainability goals.

actions.text: Develop a local food procurement policy prioritizing Limerick-grown produce for public institutions, such as schools and hospitals, to support local farmers and reduce food miles.

tasks.text: The community assembly participants could advocate for and collaborate with Limerick City and County Council at the local, regional, and national levels to create and implement a local food procurement policy that mandates the prioritization of Limerick-grown produce for public institutions, thereby supporting local farmers and reducing food miles.

updates.text:
Progress Update: 
Limerick City and County Council has begun drafting a local food procurement policy in collaboration with assembly participants. Initial meetings with farmers and public institutions have taken place to assess feasibility and gather input. The policy is on track for implementation in the coming months, pending final approval.

actions.text: Establish a Limerick Food Policy Council to coordinate and advocate for a sustainable, equitable, and resilient local food system.

tasks.text: The community assembly participants could advocate for the establishment of a Limerick Food Policy Council by engaging with Limerick City and County Council, Limerick Sustainable Food Alliance (LSFA), and other relevant stakeholders to ensure a coordinated effort in creating a sustainable, equitable, and resilient local food system.

updates.text: Six weeks on, the Limerick Food Policy Council has been officially established. Representatives from the City and County Council, LSFA, community groups, and local food businesses have begun meeting regularly to develop a comprehensive strategy for a sustainable and just food system in Limerick. Exciting progress is underway!

actions.text: Promote sustainable food packaging solutions among Limerick businesses to reduce waste and environmental impact.

tasks.text: EcoPackLimerick, Limerick City and County Council, and LSPI can collaborate to develop and implement a comprehensive sustainable packaging strategy, including incentives, regulations, and educational campaigns to encourage Limerick businesses to adopt eco-friendly packaging solutions.

updates.text: EcoPackLimerick has partnered with the Council and LSPI to launch a pilot program providing eco-friendly packaging options to 20 local businesses. Initial feedback is positive, with participating businesses reporting a 25% reduction in packaging waste. The team is now planning a larger rollout and educational campaign for later this year.

actions.text: Collaborate with cities facing similar challenges, like Dakar and Dhaka, to share best practices and advocate for global policies supporting sustainable, resilient local food systems.

tasks.text: The community assembly participants could recommend that Limerick City and County Council and Munster Regional Food Resilience Council establish formal partnerships and knowledge-sharing networks with their counterparts in Dakar and Dhaka to exchange successful strategies and jointly lobby for international policies that bolster sustainable and resilient local food systems.

updates.text: Two months on, Limerick is actively collaborating with Dakar and Dhaka. Regular virtual meetings are facilitating valuable knowledge exchange on urban farming, food waste reduction, and climate-resilient agriculture. The cities are drafting a joint policy proposal for the UN Food Systems Summit to promote local, sustainable food systems globally.

details.name: Comrat Climate Gathering
details.purpose: We are running this assembly in Comrat to bring together diverse voices from our community to discuss the challenges and opportunities around food in the face of global crises. By deliberating together, we hope to find locally relevant solutions that can contribute to a more sustainable and resilient future.
details.background: Comrat, the capital of Gagauzia, Moldova, faces challenges in food security due to its semi-arid climate, limited agricultural resources, and economic instability. The region heavily relies on imports, making it vulnerable to global food price fluctuations. Climate change exacerbates water scarcity and crop failures, while the rural population struggles with poverty and limited access to diverse, nutritious food. Addressing these issues requires local adaptation strategies, sustainable agricultural practices, and international cooperation to build resilience in the face of global systemic risks.
details.organisation_name: Asociația Comunității pentru Dezvoltare Durabilă Comrat
details.organisation_description: Asociația Comunității pentru Dezvoltare Durabilă Comrat is a grassroots organization in Comrat, Gagauzia, Moldova, promoting sustainable agriculture, local food systems, and community resilience in the face of climate change.
details.supporters_description:
Non-Governmental Organization: A local environmental NGO is partnering with Asociația Comunității pentru Dezvoltare Durabilă Comrat to provide technical expertise and resources for sustainable agriculture projects, promoting eco-friendly farming practices and helping farmers adapt to climate change.

Faith-Based Organization: The local Orthodox church is collaborating with Asociația Comunității pentru Dezvoltare Durabilă Comrat to organize community events and workshops that raise awareness about food security and the importance of sustainable food systems, while also providing a platform for community members to share their experiences and ideas.
details.funders_description: The Orthodox Church of Moldova, a prominent faith-based organization, is supporting the community assembly in Comrat, Gagauzia, Moldova as part of its mission to promote social cohesion and address pressing issues affecting the community. The Church recognizes the importance of fostering dialogue and collective decision-making in the face of challenges related to food security, environmental sustainability, and the well-being of the local population. By providing resources and moral support for the assembly, the Orthodox Church aims to strengthen the community's resilience and encourage the development of solutions that align with its values of compassion, stewardship, and unity.
details.recruitment_criteria: WHAT FORMAT? Setting demographic parameters? Living within a certain distance? Freeform text?

actions.text: Develop a community-based seed bank to preserve local crop diversity and ensure access to resilient, adaptable plant varieties for farmers in the face of climate change.

tasks.text: The community assembly participants can support the Gagauz Heritage Seed Collective in establishing a local seed bank by contributing their knowledge of traditional crop varieties, providing resources, and volunteering their time to help collect, catalogue, and store seeds.

updates.text: The Gagauz Heritage Seed Collective has made significant strides in establishing a community seed bank. Volunteers have collected and catalogued over 50 traditional crop varieties, with more being added each week. Construction of the seed storage facility is underway, thanks to generous donations of materials and labor from the community.

The community seed bank inspired similar initiatives across Moldova, leading to a national network of seed savers. This caught the attention of the government, which is now considering legislation to support and protect these vital resources for climate resilience and food security.

actions.text: Establish a regional food reserve to buffer against supply chain disruptions and price shocks, ensuring stable access to staple foods during crises.

tasks.text: Participants could advocate for increased funding and resources to be allocated to the Gagauzian Regional Food Security Council, Gagauzian Regional Food Security Initiative (GRFSI), and Gagauzian National Food Security Administration to establish and maintain a well-stocked regional food reserve.

updates.text: The Gagauzian Regional Food Security Council has secured funding to expand the regional food reserve. Construction of new storage facilities is underway, and the GRFSI has begun stockpiling staple foods. The reserve is on track to provide a 6-month buffer for the region's population by the end of the year.

actions.text: Promote agroforestry practices that integrate drought-resistant tree crops with traditional agriculture to improve soil health, water retention, and crop resilience in the face of climate change.

tasks.text: The community assembly participants could support the Gagauzian Agroforestry Alliance (GAA) in implementing agroforestry practices by providing local knowledge, volunteering labor, and advocating for policies that incentivize the adoption of drought-resistant tree crops and sustainable agriculture techniques.

updates.text: Two months on, the GAA has planted over 500 drought-resistant trees on local farms with the help of community volunteers. Soil health is already improving. The assembly participants are now focusing their efforts on lobbying regional policymakers to introduce subsidies for farmers transitioning to agroforestry practices.

The Moldovan government, inspired by the community assembly's recommendation, has launched a nationwide agroforestry initiative. The program provides funding and technical support to farmers adopting drought-resistant tree crops and traditional agriculture practices. This initiative has caught the attention of other community assemblies worldwide, sparking a global movement towards resilient farming practices.

actions.text: Develop a community-based water management plan to improve water conservation, storage, and distribution, ensuring equitable access to water resources for agriculture and household use during dry periods.

tasks.text: The community assembly participants can support the development of a comprehensive water management plan by providing input on local water needs, challenges, and potential solutions to inform the collaborative efforts of the Comrat Municipal Water Council, Comrat Water Stewardship Initiative (CWSI), and Gagauzian Regional Water Authority (GRWA).

updates.text: The CWSI and GRWA have begun drafting the water management plan, incorporating community input. Key focus areas include improving rainwater harvesting, upgrading storage infrastructure, and implementing fair distribution systems. The plan is expected to be finalized and presented to the Comrat Municipal Water Council for approval within the next month.

The community-based water management plan, developed during the assembly, has been adopted by several neighboring communities in Moldova. This collaborative effort has caught the attention of national policymakers, who are now considering integrating key aspects of the plan into a nationwide water conservation and distribution strategy.

actions.text: Collaborate with indigenous communities in arid regions worldwide to exchange knowledge on traditional, climate-resilient agricultural practices and adapt them to the local context.

target_actors.text: Gagauzian Institute for Arid Lands Agriculture (GIALA)

tasks.text: GIAAA and GIALA can facilitate knowledge sharing workshops between Gagauz farmers and indigenous communities to identify, document, and pilot the adaptation of traditional arid agriculture techniques.

updates.text:
Progress Update:
GIAAA and GIALA organized virtual knowledge sharing workshops connecting Gagauz farmers with indigenous communities from Australia and Morocco. Participants exchanged insights on traditional water conservation and crop selection techniques. Pilot projects are being designed to adapt these practices in Gagauzia, with field trials planned for the upcoming growing season.

details.name: Mahé Climate Meeting
details.purpose: We are running this assembly to bring together diverse voices from Victoria, Mahé to discuss the challenges and opportunities around food in the context of global crises. Our goal is to foster meaningful dialogue and generate innovative solutions that can help build a more sustainable and resilient food system.
details.background: Victoria, the capital of Seychelles, faces challenges related to food security and sustainability. As a small island nation, Seychelles relies heavily on imported food, making it vulnerable to global supply chain disruptions and price fluctuations. Climate change poses threats to local agriculture and fisheries, which are essential for food production and livelihoods. The assembly in Victoria aims to address these issues by exploring ways to strengthen local food systems, promote sustainable practices, and build resilience in the face of global crises, while considering the unique context of Seychelles and its limited land resources.
details.organisation_description: Sesel Manze Dirab is a grassroots movement in Victoria, Mahé, Seychelles, advocating for sustainable fishing practices, equitable access to nutritious food, and support for local farmers and fishermen.
details.supporters_description:
Activist Network: The activist network in Victoria, Mahé, Seychelles, is actively supporting the Sesel Manze Dirab movement by organizing peaceful protests, rallies, and community events to raise awareness about food justice issues. They are also engaging in door-to-door campaigns, distributing informational pamphlets, and using social media platforms to spread the message and garner support for the movement. The network is collaborating with local farmers, fishermen, and food producers to promote sustainable and equitable food practices.

Philanthropic Organization: A local philanthropic organization based in Victoria, Mahé, Seychelles, has pledged financial support to the Sesel Manze Dirab movement. They are providing grants to fund community gardens, educational programs on sustainable agriculture, and initiatives that aim to improve access to healthy, affordable food for marginalized communities. The organization is also working closely with the activist network to identify areas where their resources can be most effectively utilized to further the goals of the food justice movement.
details.funders_description: The Seychelles Farmers and Fishers Association (SFFA), a community-based organization in Victoria, Mahé, Seychelles, is supporting the community assembly to discuss sustainable food practices and the challenges faced by local farmers and fishers. The SFFA aims to promote dialogue between community members, share traditional knowledge, and develop strategies to enhance food security and resilience in the face of climate change and other environmental pressures affecting the island nation.
details.recruitment_criteria: WHAT FORMAT? Setting demographic parameters? Living within a certain distance? Freeform text?

actions.text: Develop a comprehensive plan to expand urban agriculture and community gardens in Victoria to increase local food production and reduce dependence on imports.

tasks.text: Community assembly participants could advocate to Victoria City Council and collaborate with Green Roots Victoria to create a detailed proposal for expanding urban agriculture and community gardens across the city.

updates.text: Progress Update: Green Roots Victoria has drafted a proposal for expanding urban agriculture and community gardens, incorporating input from the community assembly. The proposal outlines potential sites, resource requirements, and a timeline for implementation. Meetings with Victoria City Council are scheduled to discuss the plan and secure support.

The Victoria urban agriculture initiative has inspired similar projects in other Seychelles communities. The national government is now considering a bill to provide funding and resources to support the expansion of local food production across the country, aiming to enhance food security and resilience in the face of global challenges.

actions.text: Invest in research and development of climate-resilient crops and agricultural practices suitable for Seychelles' unique environment and limited land resources.

target_actors.text: Seychelles Institute for Sustainable Agriculture and Climate Adaptation (SISACA)

tasks.text: The community assembly participants could advocate for increased government funding and private sector partnerships to support SISACA's research and development efforts on climate-resilient crops and agricultural practices tailored to Seychelles' specific needs.

updates.text: Progress Update: SISACA has secured government funding and established partnerships with two agribusinesses to develop drought-resistant cassava and sweet potato varieties. Field trials are underway on three islands, with promising initial results. Outreach to farmers has begun to promote adoption of these climate-smart crops and practices.

The Seychelles government, inspired by the community assembly, has partnered with international research institutions to develop a climate-resilient breadfruit variety. This new strain, now being shared with other island nations through the global assembly network, promises to enhance food security and resilience in the face of climate change.

actions.text: Establish a sustainable seafood certification program to promote responsible fishing practices and support local fisheries.

tasks.text: The community assembly participants can support the Seychelles Sustainable Seafood Initiative (SSSI) in developing criteria, conducting assessments, and raising awareness to establish a credible and effective sustainable seafood certification program.

updates.text: Two months after the assembly, the SSSI has drafted initial certification criteria and conducted a pilot assessment of three local fisheries. Community volunteers are being recruited to help refine the standards and raise awareness among consumers and businesses. Progress is steady as the program takes shape.

actions.text: Promote the cultivation and consumption of locally-grown, nutrient-dense crops like moringa and breadfruit to improve nutrition and reduce reliance on imported processed foods.

tasks.text: SSFI can provide training, resources, and support to local farmers to grow moringa, breadfruit, and other nutritious crops, while also educating the community about the benefits of consuming these locally-grown foods.

updates.text: Since the assembly, SSFI has trained 25 local farmers in cultivating moringa and breadfruit. Educational campaigns have reached over 500 community members, highlighting the nutritional benefits of these crops. Local markets have seen a 15% increase in sales of moringa and breadfruit, indicating a growing shift towards locally-grown, nutrient-dense foods.

The Seychelles government has launched a nationwide campaign to encourage the cultivation of moringa and breadfruit, inspired by the community assembly's recommendations. Subsidies and training programs are now available to farmers, and public institutions are incorporating these nutrient-rich crops into their menus, setting an example for the entire country.

actions.text: Collaborate with other small island nations to advocate for increased support from the international community in addressing food security challenges exacerbated by climate change.

target_actors.text: Seychelles National Food Security and Climate Resilience Council

tasks.text: The community assembly participants could draft a joint resolution calling on the Seychelles Archipelago Regional Council, Small Island Food Security Alliance (SIFSA), and Seychelles National Food Security and Climate Resilience Council to work together to develop a coordinated advocacy strategy for engaging the international community on providing increased support to address the unique food security challenges facing small island nations due to climate change.

updates.text:
Progress Update:
The Seychelles delegation met with SIFSA representatives to draft a joint resolution. Collaborative working groups have been established to develop an advocacy strategy. Initial outreach to international organizations has begun, with plans for a high-level summit to present the resolution and garner support within the next quarter.

details.name: Rarotonga Community Meeting
details.purpose: We are running this assembly in Avarua to bring our community together to discuss the challenges and opportunities around food in the face of climate change and other global crises. We want to hear diverse local perspectives to help shape a more sustainable and resilient food future for Rarotonga.
details.background: Avarua, the capital of the Cook Islands, faces challenges related to food security and sustainability. As a small island nation, it is vulnerable to the impacts of climate change, such as rising sea levels and extreme weather events, which threaten local agriculture and fisheries. The reliance on imported processed foods has led to high rates of obesity and diet-related health issues. Avarua's assembly aims to address these concerns by promoting local food production, traditional knowledge, and sustainable practices, while also considering the broader global context of food systems and their interconnectedness with environmental and social issues.
details.organisation_description: Ngaoa Turepu, a 45-year-old fisherman from Avarua, Rarotonga, is a respected community leader known for his traditional knowledge of sustainable fishing practices and his passion for preserving the island's marine ecosystem.
details.supporters_description:
Local Government: The Avarua City Council is providing a venue for Ngaoa Turepu's community assembly meetings and assisting with logistical support, such as setting up the space and providing basic refreshments for participants.

International Organization: The United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) Pacific Office is offering technical expertise to help facilitate the deliberative process, providing guidance on best practices for inclusive dialogue and decision-making. The UNDP is also helping to document the outcomes of the assembly for potential policy recommendations.
details.funders_description: The Avarua Community Garden Association, a local community-based organization, is supporting the community assembly in Avarua, Rarotonga, Cook Islands. They believe that discussing food security and sustainability is crucial for the well-being of their community, especially in the face of climate change and its impact on the island's agricultural practices. By providing a platform for the assembly, they aim to foster dialogue, share traditional knowledge, and develop community-driven solutions to ensure a resilient and sustainable food system for the people of Avarua.
details.recruitment_criteria: WHAT FORMAT? Setting demographic parameters? Living within a certain distance? Freeform text?

actions.text: Develop a community-based agroforestry program that integrates traditional crops and farming practices to enhance local food production and resilience against climate change impacts.

tasks.text: The community assembly participants can support Te Vai Ora Agroforestry Initiative by sharing their knowledge of traditional crops and farming practices, volunteering their time and skills, and helping to secure funding and resources for the program.

updates.text: Two months on, the Te Vai Ora Agroforestry Initiative has made significant strides. Community elders have shared invaluable traditional farming knowledge, while enthusiastic volunteers have begun planting diverse crops. The team has also submitted grant proposals to secure funding for expanding the program and enhancing local food resilience.

The agroforestry initiative has inspired similar projects across the Cook Islands, with government support for scaling up. Insights are being shared with community assemblies worldwide through a new online knowledge hub, fostering collaboration on climate-resilient food solutions. The UN has praised the program as a model for sustainable development.

actions.text: Establish a community seed bank to preserve and share traditional crop varieties adapted to local conditions, promoting biodiversity and food security.

target_actors.text: Te Kākano Ora Community Seed Bank

tasks.text: Te Kākano Ora Community Seed Bank, Rarotonga Heritage Seed Collective, and Avarua District Council can collaborate to create a community seed bank that collects, stores, and distributes traditional crop varieties, ensuring their preservation and availability for local farmers and gardeners.

updates.text: Te Kākano Ora Community Seed Bank has been established in collaboration with the Rarotonga Heritage Seed Collective and Avarua District Council. Over 50 traditional crop varieties have been collected and stored, with plans for distribution to local farmers and gardeners in the coming planting season.

actions.text: Implement a farm-to-school program that connects local farmers with schools to provide fresh, nutritious meals and educate students about sustainable food systems.

target_actors.text: Te Puna Kai o te Kura

tasks.text: Participants can advocate for and support the collaboration between Avarua District Council, Te Puna Kai o te Kura, and Rarotonga Sustainable Food Education Network (RSFEN) to establish a comprehensive farm-to-school program that sources local produce for school meals and incorporates educational components on sustainable food systems.

updates.text: 27 schools across Rarotonga have now joined the farm-to-school program, with over 80% of produce being sourced from local farmers. Te Puna Kai o te Kura and RSFEN have developed a curriculum on sustainable food systems, and 12 farmers have hosted educational visits for hundreds of students.

actions.text: Create a network of small-scale fisheries across Pacific island nations to share sustainable practices, protect marine ecosystems, and advocate for their rights in global climate negotiations.

tasks.text: PISFA can facilitate knowledge sharing, coordinate conservation efforts, and amplify the voices of small-scale fishers in global forums to promote sustainable practices and protect the livelihoods and marine resources of Pacific island communities.

updates.text: The Pacific Island Sustainable Fisheries Alliance (PISFA) has connected over 20 small-scale fisheries across 10 nations. Two virtual knowledge-sharing sessions were held, with plans for in-person exchanges. PISFA representatives will attend the upcoming UN Ocean Conference to advocate for sustainable fishing practices and climate resilience measures.

The Pacific Island Sustainable Fisheries Network, formed after the assembly, has successfully lobbied for the inclusion of small-scale fisheries' rights and marine conservation in the upcoming COP28 climate negotiations. The network is now expanding to include more island nations, strengthening their collective voice on the global stage.

details.name: Brikama Community Gathering
details.purpose: We are running this assembly to bring together diverse voices from our community to discuss the challenges and opportunities around food in the face of climate change, biodiversity loss, and other global crises. Our goal is to develop locally-relevant solutions that can help build a more resilient future.
details.background: Brikama, a rapidly growing city in the West Coast Region of Gambia, faces challenges in ensuring food security for its population. Climate change, soil degradation, and limited agricultural resources strain local food production. The city's proximity to the coast makes it vulnerable to rising sea levels and erosion. Brikama's food system is also influenced by global trade, import dependencies, and fluctuating food prices. Addressing these interconnected issues requires a holistic approach that considers local needs and global dynamics to build a resilient and sustainable food future for the community.
details.organisation_description: Brikama Workers' Solidarity Union, based in Brikama, West Coast Region, Gambia, is a labor union representing workers across various industries, advocating for fair wages, safe working conditions, and workers' rights.
details.supporters_description:
Regional Government:
The West Coast Regional Council has provided a grant to the Brikama Workers' Solidarity Union to support their initiatives in promoting fair labor practices and workers' rights. The council also facilitates regular meetings between union representatives and local businesses to foster dialogue and collaboration.

For-Profit Business:
Gambia Horticultural Enterprises, a major employer in Brikama, has partnered with the Brikama Workers' Solidarity Union to implement improved working conditions and benefits for its employees. The company also sponsors union-led training programs to enhance workers' skills and productivity.
details.funders_description: The Brikama Area Council, the local government authority in the West Coast Region of Gambia, is supporting the community assembly as part of its commitment to promoting participatory governance and engaging citizens in decision-making processes. The council recognizes the importance of addressing food security and sustainability issues in the context of global challenges and believes that the community assembly will provide valuable insights and recommendations to inform local policies and initiatives.
details.recruitment_criteria: WHAT FORMAT? Setting demographic parameters? Living within a certain distance? Freeform text?

actions.text: Develop urban agriculture initiatives to increase local food production and reduce reliance on imports.

tasks.text: The community assembly participants could advocate for and support Brikama Municipal Council in establishing urban gardens, rooftop farms, and community allotments to boost local food production within the city.

updates.text: Progress Update: The Brikama Municipal Council has allocated land for three new urban gardens and approved permits for five rooftop farms. Community members have formed a volunteer committee to manage the allotments and provide training. Seeds and tools have been donated by local businesses, and planting is underway.

The Gambian government, inspired by the community assembly's proposal, has launched a nationwide urban agriculture program. Grants and training are being provided to help cities across the country establish community gardens and rooftop farms, with the goal of boosting local food security and resilience.

actions.text: Promote agroforestry practices that integrate trees into farming systems to improve soil health, increase crop yields, and provide additional income sources for farmers.

target_actors.text: Brikama Institute for Sustainable Agroforestry and Rural Development (BISARD)

tasks.text: The community assembly participants can support the collaboration between BAA and BISARD to conduct training workshops and establish demonstration plots showcasing agroforestry techniques that enhance soil fertility, productivity, and farmer livelihoods.

updates.text: 37 farmers attended agroforestry workshops by BAA and BISARD. 5 demonstration plots were established, integrating nitrogen-fixing trees and fruit trees with crops. Early results show improved soil moisture retention and crop growth. More workshops are planned to reach additional farmers and promote wider adoption of agroforestry practices.

actions.text: Establish a community seed bank to preserve local crop diversity and ensure access to climate-resilient seeds for farmers.

tasks.text: The community assembly participants could support the establishment of the seed bank by volunteering their time, donating seeds, and advocating for funding and resources to be allocated to the Brikama Community Seed Savers Cooperative and Brikama Seed Savers Collective.

updates.text: The Brikama Seed Savers Collective has secured a location for the community seed bank. Volunteers have begun cataloging donated seeds from local farmers. Advocacy efforts are underway to secure additional funding for proper storage equipment. The cooperative is planning educational workshops on seed saving techniques for the coming months.

The Gambian government, inspired by the community assembly's seed bank initiative, has launched a national program to support the establishment of seed banks in every region. This program aims to enhance food security and promote climate-resilient agriculture throughout the country, in collaboration with local communities and international partners.

actions.text: Develop a community-based coastal protection program to combat erosion and rising sea levels, safeguarding agricultural land and food production.

tasks.text: Community assembly participants could support the development of a collaborative, multi-stakeholder coastal protection program by BCRI, Brikama Municipal Council, and West Coast Regional Council through providing local knowledge, mobilizing volunteers, and advocating for necessary resources and policies.

updates.text: Two months after the assembly, BCRI has partnered with local councils to design a coastal protection plan. Community volunteers have been recruited and trained. Baseline studies of at-risk areas are underway. Next steps include securing funding, finalizing designs, and beginning construction of natural barriers to mitigate erosion.

The Gambian government, inspired by the community assembly's proposal, has launched a nationwide initiative to support local coastal protection programs. The initiative includes funding, technical assistance, and knowledge sharing among communities facing similar challenges, aiming to enhance food security and resilience against climate change-induced sea level rise.

actions.text: Establish a food waste reduction and redistribution network to address food insecurity and minimize waste in Brikama.

tasks.text: The community assembly participants can support the collaboration between BFRA and BFRI to create a comprehensive plan for collecting surplus food, storing it safely, and distributing it to those in need, while also educating the community about reducing food waste.

updates.text:
Progress Update:
BFRA and BFRI have partnered to develop a food waste reduction and redistribution plan. Two community workshops were held to educate residents about minimizing waste. A pilot program has begun, with volunteers collecting surplus food from local markets and distributing it to identified food-insecure households.

The Brikama food waste reduction network has inspired similar initiatives across Gambia. The government is now considering national legislation to mandate food waste reduction and redistribution programs in all major cities, aiming to halve food insecurity and waste by 2030 in line with the UN Sustainable Development Goals.

actions.text: Collaborate with indigenous communities in the Amazon to share knowledge on sustainable farming practices and protect their land rights, ensuring global food security and biodiversity conservation.

target_actors.text: Brikama Indigenous Peoples' Alliance for Sustainable Agriculture (BIPASA)
Global Alliance for Indigenous Amazonian Agroecology (GAIAA)

tasks.text: BIPASA, AISAN, and GAIAA can facilitate knowledge exchange, provide resources, and advocate for policies that support indigenous land rights and sustainable farming practices in the Amazon.

updates.text: Two months on, BIPASA has connected with Amazonian indigenous leaders to plan knowledge-sharing workshops. AISAN secured funding for sustainable farming initiatives. GAIAA met with policymakers to discuss strengthening indigenous land rights. The organizations are working together to support Amazonian communities in preserving biodiversity and ensuring global food security.

details.name: Dakar Climate Conversation
